componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Expedia's Q4 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Alan Pickerill, Vice President of Investor Relations at Expedia. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everybody, and welcome to Expedia Inc.'s conference call for the fourth quarter and full year 2015.I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okerstrom, CFO and EVP o
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everybody, and welcome to Expedia Inc.'s conference call for the fourth quarter and full year 2015.
I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okerstrom, CFO and EVP of Operations.
The following discussion, including responses to your questions, reflects management's views as of today, February 10, 2016, only. We do not undertake any obligation to update or revise this information.
As always, some of the statements made on today's call are forward-looking, typically preceded by words such as we expect, we believe, we anticipate or similar statements. Please refer to today's press release and the company's filings with the SEC for information about factors, which could cause our actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements.
You'll find reconciliations of our non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures discussed today in our earnings release, which is posted on the company's IR website at ir.expediainc.com. I encourage you to periodically visit our Investor Relations site for important content, including today's earnings release and an updated investor deck.
As a reminder, we sold our 62.4% ownership stake in eLong on May 22, 2015, which is previously a consolidated entity of Expedia, Inc. For GAAP accounting purposes, the results of eLong are included in our results through the date of the sale.  In order to allow investors to compare our current results on a like-for-like basis with our historical results, our commentary in the earnings release and on this call is principally focused on our results excluding eLong, which should be considered in addition to the GAAP results on a fully consolidated basis.
 Finally, unless otherwise stated, all references to cost of revenue, selling and marketing expense, general and administrative expense, and technology and content expense, also exclude stock-based compensation and depreciation expense. And all comparisons on this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2014.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Dara.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. I wanted to start right upfront thanking our employees all over the world for another strong year for Expedia Inc. Mark, Alan and I get to tell you about it and take public credit for the success of our company, but it's amalgamation of ever
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. I wanted to start right upfront thanking our employees all over the world for another strong year for Expedia Inc. Mark, Alan and I get to tell you about it and take public credit for the success of our company, but it's amalgamation of everyone's dedication and good work that adds up to the figures that we'll review today. And the figures tell a consistently strong story. Gross bookings for 2015, up 24% to $59.7 billion, and total revenue up 19% to $6.6 billion. Our customers bought 35% more airline tickets, 36% more room nights, totaling more than $200 million for the year and 37% more car days in 2015 versus 2014. We delivered nearly $1.2 billion of adjusted EBITDA for the year, impressive in its own right, but especially so we can consider the huge headwinds from foreign currency, the significant investments we're making and resetting our contracted margin structure with our hotel partners and the deal-related cost that we incurred in connection with our busy year of M&A activity.
Speaking of M&A, 2015 was an unprecedented year for Expedia as we completed over $6 billion of strategic acquisitions, which included Travelocity and a majority stake in our areas of joint venture, a significant minority investment in Decolar, Orbitz Worldwide and most recently, our largest acquisition ever in Home Away. These transactions have consolidated and scaled our U.S. operations, extended our international reach and have opened up a new leg of growth on the alternative accommodation sector. We also divested our stake in eLong for a nice profit and entered into a long-term alliance with Briefly on Orbitz, the integration is progressing well with nearly all of the direct type in traffic of Orbitz.com and Cheap Tickets already on the Brand Expedia platform. It's early but results so far look promising. The migration work will continue to the first half of 2016, followed by optimizing the sites and tuning their variable marketing channels post migration. We're also actively working on other parts of the Orbitz business, including ebookers, Hotel Club, Orbitz Partner Network and Orbitz for Business. Our goal is to migrate the vast majority of our Orbitz for Business clients onto the Egencia platform before year-end. We're also on active dialogue with our private label partners and expanding our relationship with them, and we see these efforts carrying through 2016 and into 2017 for partners.
Moving forward, we're planning to invest aggressively in our private label and partnership capabilities and consider this area highly strategic for our company. I'll also add that we're very pleased with the talent level and execution capability of our Orbitz teams all over the world. The people and the brands we've added to our family will play an important role in our future success.
It's very early but we're encouraged with the Home Away's Q4 performance coming in a bit ahead of our expectations and have been consistently impressed with the level of talent. They operated largely as a stand-alone business and will serve as the end-to-end vacation rental and home sharing platform for Expedia Inc. family. That said, we plan to be highly involved with the Home Away team, helping them expand aggressively and move from their traditional listings model to fully online transactional model. The team is beginning to introduce service fee to travelers, and we expect that it will be fully launched on as a U.S. vacation rental listings in the coming months slightly ahead of schedule. On the same time, we're rolling out supply commissions for paper bookings as well as a booklet confidence guarantee, which is designed to encourage travelers to book on Home Away and give them increased peace of mind when they do. We started an integrated marketing campaign in some of our major markets and intend to reinvest incremental upside from travel fees back into the business, particularly in product, technology and marketing. We remain confident in our estimate of $350 million in adjusted EBITDA for Home Away in 2018.
We continue to see strong growth for trivago in Q4 and, in fact, for all of 2015. We've had some investor questions in regards to trivago's core growth and profitability, and we'd like to share some numbers for European markets versus the rest of the world. To take out the noise created by foreign exchange fluctuations, the numbers here are stated hero. Trivago delivered 2015 stand-alone revenue of roughly EUR 490 million, up nearly 60% year-over-year with adjusted EBITDA of a few million euro. Now within these numbers, their most mature European markets collectively had revenue of over EUR 250 million, up 20% year-over-year and with the contribution margin after direct marketing cost of about 25%. trivago's rest of the world markets had revenue of EUR 235 million, up nearly 130% and a contribution margin just above breakeven. Note also that overhead cost for trivago had been running in the neighborhood of 10% of revenue. While we expect trivago to achieve healthy top and bottom line growth in 2016, we'll continue to reinvest profits from core markets to further scale expansion markets on a worldwide basis. The trivago team is first rate, and we believe the global growth run rate for this brand continues to be substantial.
Lastly, underpinning our active M&A strategy investment in high-growth businesses is a core organic business that has never been stronger. Brand Expedia, Hotels.com, our Expedia Affiliate Network business, all had terrific years delivering healthy adjusted EBITDA growth. Egencia, our corporate travel business had another excellent year, signing up over 1.1 billion of new client business and delivering 12% adjusted EBITDA growth. Supporting all of our brands, our lodging supply team is also firing on all cylinders, signing up nearly 60,000 new directly contracted hotel properties in 2015, up over 30% year-on-year.
Since I opened my remarks with our accomplishments as a company, I'll close with some thoughts about key challenges. Competition for consumer attention is as strong as ever as our competitors, and in some case, our partners, invest and innovate aggressively. We're also jumping into the alternative accommodations space where there's already a sizable competitor and where we have a significant business model transition to undertake at Home Away. And as I described, we have heavy integration work with Orbitz. These matters, along with a volatile global macroeconomic climate, together create a very dynamic and challenging environment to say the least. That said, our business and our teams are no strangers to these constant challenges. We're focused, we're hungry. We have an established execution and capital allocation record and you take these challenges head-on and with confidence.
With that, I'll hand it to Mark.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dara. One quick reminder before I get started, as with the case last quarter, in order to help the comparability, our comments today are focused on Expedia results excluding eLong since we sold our 62% in eLong last May. Financial results for that
componenttext:
Thanks, Dara. One quick reminder before I get started, as with the case last quarter, in order to help the comparability, our comments today are focused on Expedia results excluding eLong since we sold our 62% in eLong last May. Financial results for that business are included in our GAAP results on a consolidated basis through the date of the sale. We were quite pleased with our financial performance in the fourth quarter and for the full year 2015, excluding an estimated headwind of $10 million to $15 million from the impact of the terrorist attacks in Paris and the negative impact of Home Away in the quarter not contemplated in our prior guidance. Our full year 2015 adjusted EBITDA growth exceeded the guidance we gave on our Q3 call. In the fourth quarter, top line growth was driven by solid unit growth across products, geographies and major brands but, first, we are getting a boost as we consolidate Orbitz. But despite the law of large numbers, our organic growth rates continue to be very healthy and comparable to the rates of growth we have seen for the last couple of years. In hotel, revenue grew 24% on room night growth of 39%. The inorganic contributions to hotel revenue and room night growth were 14 and 15 percentage points, respectively. We estimate the negative impact from Paris was around 300 basis points for both measures. Revenue per room night was 11% in Q4 and on a 5% decline in average daily rates. Note that the gap between revenue per room night and ADRs narrowed this quarter compared to Q3, principally on reduced foreign exchange impacts. We do expect to see continued year-over-year pressure on revenue per room night in 2016 as we create some of our unit economics to drive volume and global scale. Air revenue was up 61% on ticket growth of 70%, partially offset by decline in revenue per ticket of 5%. Brand Expedia continued to grow ticket volume at healthy organic rate along with sizable contributions from recently acquired companies. Excluding acquisitions, air revenue grew 6% on ticket growth of 22%. Key to our strategy is to grow additional travel products alongside air tickets and room nights. We are pleased to see some good examples of this in Q4, including 66% transaction growth for our local activities business and 43% revenue growth for insurance product. We also continue to see solid growth in our Advertising & Media business with trivago growing stand-alone revenue 27% or approximately 43% currency-neutral, fairly consistent with the year-over-year growth we saw in Q3. Media Solutions also grew revenue nicely with the boost from the addition of Orbitz. Home Away finished 2015 strongly and a bit ahead of their plans as measured on a stand-alone basis. For Expedia Inc., Home Away contributed revenue this quarter for approximately $20 million, which has been classified as other revenue in our product classification. We are breaking out Home Away as a separate segment, so you will be expected to see the stand-alone performance on an ongoing basis. Because Home Away is in the process of moving to an online booking model and a fair bit of the booking still occur outside of the platform, we are not planning to report gross bookings or unit growth for that business at this time. Although the seasonality of our business can cause the shape of our P&L to vary quarter-to-quarter, we continue to drive the results that use leverage achieved in key expense categories to fund aggressive selling and marketing investments around the world. In Q4, excluding the impact from Orbitz and Home Away, the P&L we delivered was largely consistent with this approach. Selling and marketing grew a bit faster than revenue, while cost of revenue and G&A grew slower, providing leverage. Our technology and content expense did grow faster than revenue and nearly 60 percentage points faster than Q3 on a combination of higher people cost along with lower capitalization rates. We continue to scale up our core infrastructure and Brand Expedia technology teams to support organic growth and to drive the integration of our annual OTA brands. And as such, we are expecting elevated technology and content expense growth at least for the first half of 2016. Importantly, our results for Q4 included the first full quarter of Orbitz and the layering in of the Home Away stand-alone financials for the 17 days of the quarter that we own the business. The operations of Orbitz for a full quarter along with deal-related and integration costs resulted in approximate breakeven adjusted EBITDA contribution for that business in Q4, which included a purchase accounting revenue headwind of approximately $27 million. Overall, the Orbitz results were a bit better than we had expected on a combination of lower integration costs and better overall performance. Home Away had a negative impact on adjusted EBITDA $14 million in Q4 not contemplated in the guidance we gave on our Q3 call. This included the results of the business, the negative impact of deal-related costs and a purchase accounting revenue headwind of approximately $6 million. Briefly, as we enter a new year, I'd like to remind folks of a few key aspects of how we manage the business. We are committed to striking the balance between delivering healthy profit growth in the near and midterm while making key investments in our business that will allow us to grow sustainably over many years to come. From a practical perspective, this means that when we see certain upside and/or outperformance for month-to-month to quarter-to-quarter, including from acquisitions, we have a bias to reinvest at least a portion of that upside back into the business. As part of this approach, we do not guide to quarterly results, and investors should not expect to see the full amount of organic overperformance or M&A-related windfalls drop immediately to the bottom line. This is an important tenet for how we are running our business, and we want investors to fully understand this approach.
Turning to our financial expectations for 2016. On a consolidated basis including all of the businesses we won today and excluding eLong, we are expecting full year adjusted EBITDA to grow in the range of 35% to 45% year-over-year. The contribution to this result from a full year of Orbitz and Home Away combined is expected to be in the range of $275 million to $325 million. In terms of the shape of the year, we are expecting particular pressure on Q1 adjusted EBITDA. Due to the seasonal nature of our business, back-end loading of adjusted EBITDA dollar growth is not unusual though we do expect the impact will be specially acute in 2016. This is due primarily to the integration of Orbitz and the timing of synergy realization, which will ramp in the back half of the year along with the transition of Home Away. As a further reminder, note that we lapped our acquisition of in the fourth quarter of 2015 and will lap both the Travelocity acquisition and the consolidation of the Air Asia Expedia joint venture in Q1, which will create tougher comps. Further, the rollout of TripAdvisor's Instant Book product will also likely continue to be a small headwind on room night growth in 2016 with an insignificant impact on profitability. From an expense standpoint, including Orbitz and Home Away, while we will see leverage and cost of revenue and general and administrative expenses in 2016, we expect technology and content expenses to grow faster than revenue, primarily driven by integration efforts and the inorganic impacts of our recent acquisitions. Regarding taxes, as you might imagine, there's lots of moving parts, especially related to newly acquired companies and our international versus domestic mix. However, we currently expect effective tax rates in the mid-20% range.
Finally, some directional color on our CapEx trends. In 2015, we saw significant capital growth with about half of the dollar growth attributable to the purchase of our future headquarters. Spending for real estate, in general, also was elevated as we continue to grow our market management team aggressively and built out new office space around the world. In addition, we invested heavily in servers and other hardware in anticipation of future organic growth and upcoming integrations. To a lesser extent, an increase in capitalized software development cost also contributed to year-over-year CapEx growth. For 2016, we expect a much more moderate pace of CapEx growth, most of which will be driven by the inorganic impact of recent acquisitions.
With that, let's move to Q&A. Operator, will you please remind participants how to queue up for questions?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe 2 quick ones for Dara and 1 for Mark, house keeping. First, Dara, can you talk about the macro environment? Obviously, a lot of fears with some of the RevPAR data out there, what you're seeing maybe U.S. and Europe. And then a lot of us have read it
componenttext: Maybe 2 quick ones for Dara and 1 for Mark, house keeping. First, Dara, can you talk about the macro environment? Obviously, a lot of fears with some of the RevPAR data out there, what you're seeing maybe U.S. and Europe. And then a lot of us have read it. Really interesting commentary on the Home Away acquisition. In there is a 2018 number of $2.34 billion in EBITDA. Can you comment on that number at all? How important that is? Is that something a target or how you think about that number? And then Mark, just to confirm your guidance, is the number you're suggesting 35% to 45% growth, is that off the 1 1 6 5 or the 1 1 0 3 in EBITDA this year?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And as far as the macro environment goes, we listen to the same news that you do and certainly, the news suggests that the macro environment is pretty uncertain and the stock market downward scary. That said, when you look at the macro environment a
componenttext: Sure. And as far as the macro environment goes, we listen to the same news that you do and certainly, the news suggests that the macro environment is pretty uncertain and the stock market downward scary. That said, when you look at the macro environment and how it affects our business, 1 important factor in our business is the air business. And air ticket prices are down pretty significantly year-on-year. It's obviously some of the savings of oil prices that are being passed on by the airlines to consumers, and that's an unambiguous positive for us. The more I -- the lower air ticket prices go, the more the leisure traveler tends to fly. And the more the leisure traveler tends to fly, as you know, we have a bit of what we think is a strategic investment, strategic advantage on the air side. And the more these travelers we have flying, the more opportunity we have to sell hotels and insurance and cars and everything else to that. So to some extent, we think some oil on the air side is a pretty big positive for us. On the hotel side, while we have seen ADRs weaken a bit between the beginning of the year and Q4, when we look at Q4 trends into January, we don't see anything of note one way or the other. There are some spot issues, obviously, Paris' week, which is perfectly explainable. New York ADRs continue to be down year-on-year over -- although they've improved over Q4, and that's European travelers really traveling into the U.S. and the effect of foreign exchange. In Asia, we see certain markets, like Hong Kong and Macao, down as far as ADRs go. But again, no significant shifts when you look at Q4 trends into January that are of note. So it's something that we'll watch. And to the extent that we see anything, we'll certainly share with our investors, but we're not seeing any material movement one way or the other right now.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on your question on 2018 consolidated EBITDA that was contained in the S-4. Listen. At the time of the acquisition, we put forward some forecasts for what we believed were a possible outcome for consolidated Expedia Inc. results over the cou
componenttext: And then just on your question on 2018 consolidated EBITDA that was contained in the S-4. Listen. At the time of the acquisition, we put forward some forecasts for what we believed were a possible outcome for consolidated Expedia Inc. results over the course of the next 3 years, did not account any upsides or any significant investments. It's a possible outcome, so I wouldn't put a lot of weight on that. That has been combined essentially with the Home Away projections and we did not, at that time, contribute to the combination of those results. So listen, I think you could look at it as a possible outcome, but it's certainly not something that I would use us guidance. And I think, as you know, we make discrete decisions from month-to-month, quarter-to-quarter, so there's a lot that can change between now and 2018, and we're just really focused on continuing to have a business where we can deliver consistently strong growth rates over a long period of time. In terms of the guidance, the 35% to 45% growth is off of the $1.165 billion, which is the Expedia Inc. full year 2015 number excluding eLong.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions and one just a follow-up on Justin's question. So if you do that 35 to 45, it kind of implies that the core business is going to grow -- your guidance implies something like 9% or 10% at the low end, 19% at the high end. So call it 10% to 20
componenttext: Two questions and one just a follow-up on Justin's question. So if you do that 35 to 45, it kind of implies that the core business is going to grow -- your guidance implies something like 9% or 10% at the low end, 19% at the high end. So call it 10% to 20% around here, and that's obviously a little more aggressive than the kind of guidance for the core business you gave going into '15. So it does sound like all-in, business are getting stronger for Expedia, but I just want to make sure I'm interpreting the numbers and stating that right. And then secondly, in terms of you guided for revenue continuing to come down in 15, and the question I want to ask is will it come down at the same pace, accelerated pace or less of a strong pace? In other words what we saw in the quarter was that 11% year-over-year was a little bit less than we've seen in the last couple of quarters. Are we starting to see a fade down in the pressure you're seeing on revenue?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'll let Mark take most of that question, but one thing I will remind you as far as the core business is that foreign exchange was a really, really significant headwind for our core business this last year. And while it will continue to be a headwin
componenttext: Mark, I'll let Mark take most of that question, but one thing I will remind you as far as the core business is that foreign exchange was a really, really significant headwind for our core business this last year. And while it will continue to be a headwind in Q1, Q2, it will ease up in the back half of the year. So all things being the same, that will be a benefit in 2016 versus 2015. I'll let Mark answer the others.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just say just to get the clarify on the guidance, I would take that as core implied guidance of closer to 8% to 13%. I would take the high on Orbitz's Home Away impact and subtract it from the high on the total and the low from the low side. I w
componenttext: Yes, I'll just say just to get the clarify on the guidance, I would take that as core implied guidance of closer to 8% to 13%. I would take the high on Orbitz's Home Away impact and subtract it from the high on the total and the low from the low side. I wouldn't take our guidance as being up to 19%. And then revenue per room night, we've been saying for a while that the gap between revenue per room night, you can think about that as, call it, the 300 to 800 basis point range, and it moves around. I think what you'll see in 2016 is you're going to continue to see that range of movement towards the back half. I think there's a possibility as we start the comp over some of the margin we did last year that start to ease, and then I think they'll start to see I would expect some more easing in that as we move through 2017. And again, this is with regards to the gap between revenue per room night and ADRs, of course, because ADRs are one of the biggest drivers of overall revenue per room night movements.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Naved Khan of Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: We'll go next to Naved Khan of Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Just on the Home Away, I know it's still early days for the transition, but transition on online bookings, but can you just talk about what kind of penetration rate you think you can reasonably get to by the end of this year in terms of per
componenttext: Two questions. Just on the Home Away, I know it's still early days for the transition, but transition on online bookings, but can you just talk about what kind of penetration rate you think you can reasonably get to by the end of this year in terms of percentage of the bookings happening online versus enabling the bookings? And then I have a follow-up on the guidance. So I think, Mark, you called out the contribution from the 2 acquisitions, Orbitz and Home Away, to the EBITDA number. But I think previously you talked about Orbitz seeing up synergies of up to 7 -- or in excess of $75 million. Is there any update to that number?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Why don't I take the last question first, and then Dara can chime in on Home Away. So just again on the $275 million to $325 million of adjusted EBITDA contribution for the 2 acquisitions combined, first of all, I would just remind people that on a
componenttext: Sure. Why don't I take the last question first, and then Dara can chime in on Home Away. So just again on the $275 million to $325 million of adjusted EBITDA contribution for the 2 acquisitions combined, first of all, I would just remind people that on a stand-alone basis, we have said Orbitz was on track to around $135 million of adjusted EBITDA in 2015. It came in a little bit ahead of that, but I think that this as a decent base in Home Away a little bit better than $120 million in adjusted EBITDA from 2015. They will both have purchase accounting headwinds on them in 2016, both around $10 million each. So think about that as about $20 million combined. So take that as your base. And then the way that we get to, obviously, the higher number is synergies, and a lot of that is going to come from Orbitz and it's going to come in the back half of the year. In fact in the first part of the year, our going to be in a position not unlike where we were at what they've where, we were essentially carrying almost double costs we built up teams to support the integration of the Orbitz businesses onto the Brand Expedia platforms, for example, at the same time maintaining the Orbitz existing platforms and then it's really once we get the platform transition done, which is really happening in the first half of the year for the big consumer businesses, that's when you start to see synergy realization come in, and that's really starting again in the back half of the year. And we're hopeful that by the end of the year, we should be pretty close to a run rate number, but we're not going to be even close to that in the middle of the year, and we'll probably be subbed, and that will be a detriment in the first part of the year.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as far as Home Away goes, as of the end of the year, we had about 60% of our total listings online bookable. We don't disclose the actual percentage of bookings that run through our listings and we're going to be working on increasing the percent
componenttext: And then as far as Home Away goes, as of the end of the year, we had about 60% of our total listings online bookable. We don't disclose the actual percentage of bookings that run through our listings and we're going to be working on increasing the percentage of online bookable listings in 2016 and get a much closer to 100% as much as we can. Really, we're going to be pushing online booking, offering it to our partners and that along with the book with confidence guarantee for travelers we think is going to be one for travelers. It is also going to be a win for our supply base as well. And that's really the focus of the business, we will try to obviously draw the online bookings volume, but that is really much more of a long-term goal for us as a company. And I think 2016 is going to be about kind of setting the base, making sure that the technology infrastructure is right and making sure that we're taking any and all kinks out of the online booking process to make an incredibly easy for travelers and incredibly easy for subscribers as well. We don't have a specific target for percentage of bookings going over the trends, so to speak, for 2016.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Tom White with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go next to Tom White with Macquarie.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first on room night growth. You talked a little bit about headwinds from the Booking.com Instant Booking implementation. Can you maybe comment on what sort of headwind that was in the quarter and then just a follow up on Home Away and moving ahead wi
componenttext: Just first on room night growth. You talked a little bit about headwinds from the Booking.com Instant Booking implementation. Can you maybe comment on what sort of headwind that was in the quarter and then just a follow up on Home Away and moving ahead with instituting this consumer booking fee. I guess when Home Away was independently could see how that extra margin would really help them from the fee would be really helpful in terms of competing and investing against Airbnb, but now that it's part of a bigger Expedia how you guys the benefit of that booking fee in terms of increased monetization versus the possibility that it negatively impacts kind of the consumer experience?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll start with the room night growth and then turn it over to Dara for Home Away. So there were a few headwinds for us in room night growth for the quarter. We had about 400 basis point harder call partially on the back of lapping some pretty strong g
componenttext: So I'll start with the room night growth and then turn it over to Dara for Home Away. So there were a few headwinds for us in room night growth for the quarter. We had about 400 basis point harder call partially on the back of lapping some pretty strong growth in Travelocity with a commercial agreement implementation and then also what if, which we were lapping over in the quarter, we also had about 300 basis points of room night growth impact from the Paris attacks. We estimate that both of those are pretty significant headwinds for us. In terms of the Instant Book impact, I think if you thought about that in the 100 to 200 basis point range, that would be a good barometer. And then just in terms of expectations for 2016, we are expecting to see some deceleration in room night growth as we move through the year. We're also comping over acquisitions and consolidations again in 2016. Travelocity, for example, ramping up what if on variable marketing channels, the integration of Brand Expedia Asia, so just keep those in mind and then to the extent that TripAdvisor rules out, Instant Booking more broadly, which we currently do expect them to do and we continue to not participate in that, that could be an incremental headwind and think about of that is larger than 100 to 200 basis points, could be 200 to 300 basis points but again, insignificant from the perspective of profitability.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as far as Home Away and the booking fee goes, we're going to be watching it very closely. We always want the consumer experience to be great, and we're obviously going to be watching the percentage of bookings running over the system. We think wi
componenttext: And then as far as Home Away and the booking fee goes, we're going to be watching it very closely. We always want the consumer experience to be great, and we're obviously going to be watching the percentage of bookings running over the system. We think with book with confidence guaranteed, we are going to give our consumers, our travelers a lot of confidence as far as booking with Home Away and making sure they get what they expect, making sure that they -- if they have any issues regarding quality or their deposits et cetera, they are taken care of. And then we will be launching other metrics such as the traffic to the site, the conversion rate of consumers coming look at listings, the renewal rate of our subscribers, so there are a host of other metrics that we're going to watch and meter in order to measure kind of what is a balanced approach which is we do think that we are under monetizing relative to our volume and making sure that as we move to call it market monetization rates, we are providing great experience for travelers who are coming and looking for a great place to stay at Home Away, and we are bringing great value to our supply as well. I will also remind you that the booking fee is something that has been widely accepted as far as Airbnb and TripAdvisor go. Airbnb has always had a booking fee. TripAdvisor introduced booking fees last year. Those transitions have gone very, very smoothly. Our pricing is going to be quite competitive, so this is something that has already been market tested, and we feel pretty good moving into this model based on the competition already being there.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a little bit about this second derivative effects you have, you talked about integration. So first, you connect the infrastructure and the plumbing, and then the machines and then you apply those learnings and optimize, specifically with m
componenttext: I wanted to ask a little bit about this second derivative effects you have, you talked about integration. So first, you connect the infrastructure and the plumbing, and then the machines and then you apply those learnings and optimize, specifically with maybe Orbitz or maybe even waive if that process is going under, too. Is the process lengthening at all just on the sheer scale or size of those integrations or maybe how is this process playing out currently?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, Brian, on the Orbitz side actually, really while we haven't gone through the full process, I would anticipate that Orbitz would actually be a bit quicker than Travelocity and because Orbitz team that was already in place. They had online marketin
componenttext: I'd say, Brian, on the Orbitz side actually, really while we haven't gone through the full process, I would anticipate that Orbitz would actually be a bit quicker than Travelocity and because Orbitz team that was already in place. They had online marketing team that is very sophisticated. They have an analytics team that is just excellent. So a number of the folks happen there with Orbitz, they understand these optimizations. This is something that they've done before, we're just hoping that as we move them over to our supply base and as we move our text stack, they're just going to have a machine that kind of is much smoother and better than the machine that they had to work with in the past. So we don't anticipate any hiccups as it relates to Orbitz. You never know. And at least the, trends that are seeing early on are encouraging and things looked to be on track. Home Away as a very different animal, we is not an integration. The team is going to be largely independent, and the activity with Home Away has been to make sure, frankly that, that team is not distracted as being part of being Expedia. I think we'll free up a bunch of their time to focus from call it public company activity to value-added activity, building a great consumer experience, building a great subscriber experience. And because we're very, very familiar with this transactional model, our product and technology teams are already working with them to make sure that the road maps are what they should be and I think the second area where we can add value is making sure that as this volume comes on line are as these listings, online, we are not only pushing Home Away traffic to them but also Expedia and Hotels.com traffic to them, which I think is of significant value both for the Home Away subscriber base but also for the Expedia and Hotels.com consumer base as well.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add one thing that Orbitz, which is we do have, in addition to the Orbitz Cheap Tickets business, which is the big consumer business, we also have a number of other businesses that they're going to take a little bit longer to integrate Orbitz pa
componenttext: I'll just add one thing that Orbitz, which is we do have, in addition to the Orbitz Cheap Tickets business, which is the big consumer business, we also have a number of other businesses that they're going to take a little bit longer to integrate Orbitz partner network, for example. We're super excited about that business, and we're taking the steps necessary to do that right, making sure we work with partners and come to the right outcome, for example. Orbitz for Business is another one. We're pretty excited about the speed at which we're able to move those clients over to the Egencia platform. But again, it is going to take a little bit longer and both of these transitions are new in that we have and that a lot of these before unlike the core consumer business. So in terms of synergy realization, I would just keep in mind that until those businesses are migrated off, you don't get to see the full platform of retirement benefits that you would if it was only Orbitz Cheap Tickets and ebookers that we are transitioning over.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions for you. You mentioned TripAdvisor impact room nights in 2015 to the extent that you don't participate, so could you talk about higher thinking about the model or other similar models why Expedia may or may not be interested in participat
componenttext: Just 2 questions for you. You mentioned TripAdvisor impact room nights in 2015 to the extent that you don't participate, so could you talk about higher thinking about the model or other similar models why Expedia may or may not be interested in participating and then secondly you expect the impact of the Paris attacks will continue beyond a 1- or 2-quarter time period? Or is that a relatively short term issue that you wouldn't expect to impact the business beyond Q1?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the second one first, which is you never know. Historically, these kinds of attacks have resolved fairly quickly. I'd say Paris, in general, we saw immediately kind of an effect on broader European destinations. That effect looks like it's dis
componenttext: I'll answer the second one first, which is you never know. Historically, these kinds of attacks have resolved fairly quickly. I'd say Paris, in general, we saw immediately kind of an effect on broader European destinations. That effect looks like it's disappeared, but there certainly continues to be an effect in Paris getting better, but the trends in Paris are certainly poor compared to the trends that we have seen before Q4 of last year. So I think Paris is going to continue through the year. It was a horrific event, and I think it was the kind of event that stays in people's memories, so I think that there'll be some effect going into the balance of the year, and we're going to do our best to make up for that. We're going to do our best to work with our partners over there and really continue to promote Paris as a wonderful destination that it is. So hopefully, it won't last long, but my personal feeling is there'll be some effect going into the balance of the year. As far as the Trip and Instant Book and how we view that channel, we've been very consistent about how we view any variable channel, including Instant Booking, that we look at the economics of a channel based on, call it, the immediate transaction and then we look at the economics of the transaction based on the lifestyle value of the customer, both in terms of the customer repeat rate and the percentage of the time in which those customers repeat directly with us the second and third time around. Obviously, the latter is much, much more valuable. The initial, let's say, version of Instant Book was, I think, quite unsatisfactory as far as the branding, et cetera, and representation of where the customer was really transacting with. And the latest iterations that we've seen with Booking.com and with some of the supplier direct partners, for example, Marriott, look a lot better. They look much more clear. So I would say, at this point, Instant Book looks better to us than it did when Instant Book was initially launched, but we don't have any comment as to what the ultimate decision is going to be down the road.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Stevie in for Doug. I have just a follow-up on the Home Away. So on Home Away, you guys mentioned that traveler fee in the next coming months, but could you clarify at it a bit more on the timing on the rollout plan a little more? And then could y
componenttext: This is Stevie in for Doug. I have just a follow-up on the Home Away. So on Home Away, you guys mentioned that traveler fee in the next coming months, but could you clarify at it a bit more on the timing on the rollout plan a little more? And then could you comment on your marketing approach for Home Away in 2016? And what drives the confidence on the 350 EBITDA number in 2018?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as far as Home Away goes we are rolling out now in the U.S. and the speed of the rollout is going to depend on the reaction of customers, conversion rate, how it's working out with subscribers et cetera. so the rollout will move quickly to th
componenttext: Yes, I think as far as Home Away goes we are rolling out now in the U.S. and the speed of the rollout is going to depend on the reaction of customers, conversion rate, how it's working out with subscribers et cetera. so the rollout will move quickly to the extent that we see things working out and will be debugging actively. We will then -- once we're done with a U.S. or once we're well underway with the U.S, we'll look at the rest of the world. But listen. These rollouts are live rollouts, and we don't want to come hard code a specific rollout cadence obviously want to roll it out as quickly as possible making sure that our customer experience and our subscriber experience is terrific. As far as the marketing approach for Home Away, we do plan a significant year-on-year increase in brand marketing and Home Away for 2016. That's included in the numbers of that Mark related to you. It's -- the marketing campaign has already started, and the early signs -- and we're about 5 markets and the early signs as far as visits to the Home Away sites look really good and were encouraged by the trends that we see. Once online booking really starts to expand, we will be able to throttle up variable marketing channels as we get kind of variable economics on the revenue side. One of the issues with the subscription listing product is that you don't earn money on every single transaction. You're earning money on a kind of annual subscription, so you can't necessarily bid for the incremental transaction. Once we have online booking expanded along with the traveler fee and volumes roll out there, we do think that we will be able to increase variable marketing channels, but we think that's something that's going to happen in the back half of the year as opposed to the front half of the year. And then on the question of the confidence in the $350 million EBITDA in 2018, we made those estimates based on a set of assumptions, early set of assumptions. And so far, in a couple of weeks that Home Away has been a part of the family, we are more impressed than we were when we made those assumptions. It's 2018, it's a long time from now, but I think what we wanted to communicate is that you kind of going to a company, you meet the people you take a look at the technology stack and the product road maps and either it's good news or bad news. And at this point, with Home Away, it's good news for us.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple, if I can. First, just forgive me if I missed this, but when you talked about the 2016 contribution from Orbitz in the way up 2 75 to 3 25, what is embedded in that in terms of the deferred revenue that you won't recognize. I know in the S4 [ph]
componenttext: A couple, if I can. First, just forgive me if I missed this, but when you talked about the 2016 contribution from Orbitz in the way up 2 75 to 3 25, what is embedded in that in terms of the deferred revenue that you won't recognize. I know in the S4 [ph] you said Home Away alone could be as high as 1 0 7, but is there an assumption that you can share with us around how much is excluded from that. And then, second, if I can, just curious if you could give us a sense for what you're seeing from early beta hotels on the accelerator product and kind of when you think that might roll out more broadly and what kind of impact it might have on revenue per room night headwinds you've been seeing.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take the first one and then turn it over to Dara. On the $275 million and $325 million, there's about $20 million of purchase accounting impact embedded in that. About half of it is Orbitz, half of it is Home Away. The bulk of that will unfold
componenttext: Sure. I'll take the first one and then turn it over to Dara. On the $275 million and $325 million, there's about $20 million of purchase accounting impact embedded in that. About half of it is Orbitz, half of it is Home Away. The bulk of that will unfold in the first quarter with some of the Home Away stuff taking a little bit longer to bleed off. It is -- the Home Away impact is a fair bit lower than we had anticipated/feared at the time of the acquisition. We dug in very deep with our auditors and advisers and came to that conclusion that there was a significantly larger portion of it that we can recognize than we had anticipated. So good news on that front.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as accelerator goes, listen, it's very, very early. We are training our market managers who are now going out there and explaining accelerator in market. We are -- and we're seeing in certain markets, we are seeing engagements with our hotel pa
componenttext: And as far as accelerator goes, listen, it's very, very early. We are training our market managers who are now going out there and explaining accelerator in market. We are -- and we're seeing in certain markets, we are seeing engagements with our hotel partners, the partners who have engaged with accelerator product are pretty darn happy, which is great. You want kind of clients who like a product and so we see accelerators starting to contribute to our overall numbers. In general, accelerator is a move in the direction of how marketplace model for our margins so that can bid up 1 day, you need volume they can go to base bid when they don't need volume. And also along with kind of bidding, you get the quality and content of the hotel, the -- how these hotels treat our customers, kind of the quality of service et cetera and user reviews, all mixing into a combination of the best hotel for the best customer and also economics that hoteliers want to bid at and, obviously, hopefully, economics that work out for us. So we are very early on this journey. The signs that we're seeing with accelerator so far are encouraging. We are not making aggressive assumptions in our 2016 plans for accelerator. But if any of our market manager teams are listening, we expect you to do better than the conservative plans that we have. So we are hoping for the best. We're not counting the best.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe 2. I noticed recently give an interview saying that Expedia was far from done on M&A so Dara, one for you would be our capital allocation how you think about the mix of asset you have now geographic as well as capabilities under the broader Expedia
componenttext: Maybe 2. I noticed recently give an interview saying that Expedia was far from done on M&A so Dara, one for you would be our capital allocation how you think about the mix of asset you have now geographic as well as capabilities under the broader Expedia Inc. umbrella and so how you think about allocating capital going forward towards maybe M&A and maybe continuing the strategic mission and the number 2 would be this been a lot of comments from some of the inventory side like Hilton Marriott with respect to lower commission rates and room availability. I want to get your take and how the industry dynamics play out around lower commission rates were stable commission rates versus availabilities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the M&A front, listen. We will be opportunistic as far as our capital allocation those I think that the team is more inwardly focused right now than booking to go out and aggressively acquire, although we have a terrific corporate developm
componenttext:
Sure. As far as the M&A front, listen. We will be opportunistic as far as our capital allocation those I think that the team is more inwardly focused right now than booking to go out and aggressively acquire, although we have a terrific corporate development and strategy team who are constantly talking to anyone and everyone. When we look at the portfolio of assets that we have, especially with Home Away as part of our family, we feel like we have a full portfolio. We feel like we don't have any competitive holes, and if we don't engage in any M&A for the next 2, 3 years, we'd be perfectly happy. That said, we do want to extend our international coverage. I think we have [Audio Gap] in the market. Obviously, we're very strong in leisure travel. Corporate travel we think is an enormous opportunity. It's a higher yield customers sat that our suppliers favor the demand patterns are quite complementary with leisure demand patterns and we want to get bigger. We want to scale and we see kind of growth ahead for Egencia that is a combination of organic as well as inorganic growth, and we think that's going to continue for some time going forward. And then we'll also look for kind of innovative new companies out there. Trivago, obviously, was a terrific one and it's a very
[Audio Gap]
valuable part of the family. We made some investments in Alice, for example, on the supply technology front. So we will be opportunistic wings as far as transport goes. We'll continue to be opportunistic. We'll continue to kind of shoot bullets, so to speak, and see what opportunity is out there in the world. That said, the business throws off a lot of cash flow. And historically, I'd say, before the year, there is a fair amount of capital allocation going to buybacks. And to the extent that we don't see anything external and to the extent of that we like our own stock and typically, we have liked our own stock, we will look to allocate some capital internally as well. So it's kind of the world is our oyster, and we're throwing off a lot of cash, and we will try our best not to waste it. As far as the noise and the chatter with the change et cetera, listen, we continued to be strong partners with the hotels, in general. Our volumes with independents and chains have grown significantly, and our strategy with our chain partners is no different than our overall strategy, which is to lower our base commissions, so that there is a very little friction in working with us. And then, really, any hotel whether they're a chain or independent can compete in our marketplace for share. And this is a market -- it's a big marketplace the marketplace is only growing. And if you got competitive pricing and you've got great content and you treat our customers really well and you provide excellent availability along with margins, you will do well in the marketplace. So I think that the ultimate, call it, performance of the chains and the relationship with the chains and the volume that we do chains is really going to be based on kind of chain bidding in our marketplace against independents. And in general, we see our chain volumes for a number of years, and we expect to see them healthy on a go-forward basis.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you touch on what Home Away subscriber churn has been since the acquisition, and what's your plan around subscription pricing? And then a follow-up, have you seen an increase with the vacation rental CPCs, particularly in regards to home, Airbnb closi
componenttext: Can you touch on what Home Away subscriber churn has been since the acquisition, and what's your plan around subscription pricing? And then a follow-up, have you seen an increase with the vacation rental CPCs, particularly in regards to home, Airbnb closing its funding route?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the one that I can a comment on is that renewal rates in Q4 actually improved and were the highest renewal rates for the year, so we are very happy about that. As far as an increase in vacation rental CPCs, we haven't seen anyone so I can't real
componenttext: As far as the one that I can a comment on is that renewal rates in Q4 actually improved and were the highest renewal rates for the year, so we are very happy about that. As far as an increase in vacation rental CPCs, we haven't seen anyone so I can't really comment on that.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dara, you continue to your portfolio as you adjust fee structure. So setting aside the removal of about 20,000 indirect relationships in the fourth quarter, I think you added about 73,000 in 2015. So just wondering if there's a way for you to accelerat
componenttext: So Dara, you continue to your portfolio as you adjust fee structure. So setting aside the removal of about 20,000 indirect relationships in the fourth quarter, I think you added about 73,000 in 2015. So just wondering if there's a way for you to accelerate the pace there. Additionally, I was wondering if you can give us some color on the type of incremental properties you're adding. Are these larger properties, smaller properties similar to what's already on the platform? And secondarily, I almost hate asking this question, but directionally, are you seeing the impact from countries maybe taking Europe due to the prices?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the supply question and the pacing of the supply adds, we're pretty happy with the pacing of ads to the extend we accelerate the pacing of ads to the expense that we've seen higher penetration and certain markets higher penetration means that we
componenttext: As far as the supply question and the pacing of the supply adds, we're pretty happy with the pacing of ads to the extend we accelerate the pacing of ads to the expense that we've seen higher penetration and certain markets higher penetration means that we're setting plenty of demand into a specific market which means that we can't acquire more hotels. And at this point, we are seeing kind of the growth of demand into the marketplace and the growth and supply be about right, so I would expect the same in 2016 and as we are adding more supply and as the new inventory contributes revenue into our marketplace we then go on a higher more market managers that we had in place for about 18 months, and I see no reason to change it. It certainly looks like it's working. As far as the kind of supply that we are adding, as we are adding more supply, we are tending to secondary and tertiary markets and the average number of rooms per hotel is going down. So when we look at contribution from new hotel adds, it's something we disclose it something we certainly look at internally the contribution for hotel add is going down, and it's going down because of the kind of supply that we're adding, and it's kind of working exactly to form so it's exactly what we would expect to see. As far as impacts from countries and the refugee crisis et cetera, we haven't seen significant impact other than travel to, I would say, broad areas that are affected by the refugee crisis or directly affected. It's obviously down. But we haven't seen kind of second-order stuff. So travel into Europe and general continues to be pretty healthy, and we're not seeing any significant step changes in demand patterns there.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And really, I wanted to understand come down as the marketplace takes into account how that relates for your comments on the accelerator program being very, very early. And then also there's another follow-up on just Orbitz and the EBITDA, can you quantif
componenttext: And really, I wanted to understand come down as the marketplace takes into account how that relates for your comments on the accelerator program being very, very early. And then also there's another follow-up on just Orbitz and the EBITDA, can you quantify, maybe Mark, or help us understand the cost savings related to the charges you took, I think around $130 million, $150 million led to employee severance and comp benefits pronounced in September in Orbitz.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the comment on accelerator program being early, it's literally because we just launched the program. So this is a product that we're co-complete in Q4 and we've been working with our market managers and hotel partners on launching it officially,
componenttext: As far as the comment on accelerator program being early, it's literally because we just launched the program. So this is a product that we're co-complete in Q4 and we've been working with our market managers and hotel partners on launching it officially, and that's something that will kind of continue as we move through the year. It is a bidding type of product. So as you can imagine these marketplace-type products tend to grow over a period of time as you get more players engaging and them. So it's early. We like what we see, but again, we're not making any heroic assumptions financially as it the relates to tourist accelerator program. But it's certainly a good start, and we think it's a terrific product that is going to be a real win for our hotel partners.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Ron, just on the restructuring charges and how to close the EBITDA contribution I would just say that in the $75 million run rate synergy estimate that we initially put out, a big chunk of that was headcount-related cost reductions essentially. T
componenttext: And then Ron, just on the restructuring charges and how to close the EBITDA contribution I would just say that in the $75 million run rate synergy estimate that we initially put out, a big chunk of that was headcount-related cost reductions essentially. There's a bit of revenue in there as well, but predominantly headcount-related. So I would look at the severance charges as being related very closely to that number. I would also say that in the overall big number is a fair bit of equity-related compensation, which does not show up in adjusted EBITDA obviously, so it's hard to to translate that into adjusted EBITDA impact. And a lot of that related to senior team that's not there. So hopefully, that gives you a little more color.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Sena with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Sena with Evercore ISI.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Connor on for Ken. Just to clarify, was there FX impact disclosed for the adjusted EBITDA guidance?
componenttext: This is Connor on for Ken. Just to clarify, was there FX impact disclosed for the adjusted EBITDA guidance?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Connor, there wasn't. But directionally, I could say that it was a bit more than the impact to revenue. I think about it in the 600 to 700 basis point range, maybe a little bit higher.
componenttext: Yes, Connor, there wasn't. But directionally, I could say that it was a bit more than the impact to revenue. I think about it in the 600 to 700 basis point range, maybe a little bit higher.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up, I guess, in an earlier question, you discussed the outlook for travel, for leisure travel. What's the outlook for business travel in the U.S., particularly thinking in the oil country and outside the U.S? Also, one thing has been discussed c
componenttext: Following up, I guess, in an earlier question, you discussed the outlook for travel, for leisure travel. What's the outlook for business travel in the U.S., particularly thinking in the oil country and outside the U.S? Also, one thing has been discussed car rental. What you see is the impact of the car-rental business in the U.S. and Europe? And finally, just I kind of missed the 35%, 45% EBITDA guidance is compared with what particular number for 2015?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the corporate travel and the trends that we're seeing, listen, we've got some caution the teams are cautious about client sales in general because of the macroeconomic environment, the most clear trend that we can point to relating to oil
componenttext: Sure. As far as the corporate travel and the trends that we're seeing, listen, we've got some caution the teams are cautious about client sales in general because of the macroeconomic environment, the most clear trend that we can point to relating to oil prices is in terms of our business in the Nordics. As you know, we acquired VIA and integrated into a Egencia, and we do see volumes in the Nordic regions, in general, weak, and that is very much related to oil prices being down significantly on a year-on-year basis. In general, transactions, corporate transactions look good. We're not seeing, call it, very significant spend cuts like one way or the other like we saw couple of years back. We are seeing some trading down so the revenue for transactions or gross booking for a corporate transaction is down a bit, and we think that's just cautious practice from some corporations out there trading down, call it, from premium class to economy class or taking a train instead of taking a plane. But those are, I would say, on the edges. We're not seeing some big theme one way or the other as far as corporate travel changing significantly one way or the other. As far as the car rental and the impact of Uber, our car rental businesses we think very early in its development the volume in car is up very significantly on a year-on-year basis, over 30% on a year-on-year basis, and most of that business in the U.S. And we think that it's on potential as far as our car rental business in Europe goes. So I just think that we're on a growth path at this point that is not going to be affected by Uber. We're not going to feel kind of, call it, market numbers one way or the other just because the growth rates that we have are so high. If I were to generalize them, in Q4, other trends that we saw in the car business, on the hardware side, we saw a higher concentration of call it agency bookings versus bookings, we tend to make more money on Opie bookings, so that is 1 trend that we saw but otherwise nothing to say Uber was having a material effect on the business to speak.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dara, a high-level one on loyalty programs. Obviously, Hotels.com in Orbitz have pretty high profile offerings what kind of appetite do you have for further investment behind those programs? Should these programs be expanded? Or are there other platforms
componenttext: Dara, a high-level one on loyalty programs. Obviously, Hotels.com in Orbitz have pretty high profile offerings what kind of appetite do you have for further investment behind those programs? Should these programs be expanded? Or are there other platforms and Expedia family where you should roll further ones out?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Absolutely. Also add that Expedia has pretty significant loyalty program and I believe between Hotels.com Expedia and Orbitz, we are running pretty close to 40 million loyalty members on a global basis. And I would say, our appetite here is unlimite
componenttext: Sure. Absolutely. Also add that Expedia has pretty significant loyalty program and I believe between Hotels.com Expedia and Orbitz, we are running pretty close to 40 million loyalty members on a global basis. And I would say, our appetite here is unlimited. And the way to explain to that is that the variable economics began these loyalty programs are all working. In other words, we look at the points cost, we look at the ultimate redemption value of those points a percentage of people who are using points, our customers who are using the points and when to use them. And then we look at the behavior of consumers and like-for-like consumers who are in the program versus the behavior of consumers who are not in the program and how that behavior changes in terms of repeat characteristics and in terms of channel mix. When you look at those factors and compare it to the point costs, these loyalty programs work. So as long as the factors are not changing, as long as these repeat characteristics aren't changing, the channel mix isn't changing and as long as the ultimate redemption value isn't changing, then we look to extend these loyalty programs as aggressively as we can on a global basis. There are some countries where the programs worked really, really well. For example, we've been pleasantly surprised and Asia Pacific regions where loyalty is really taking off and, for example, on our welcome rewards basis, it's got the highest penetration of welcome rewards or hotel rewards. It's got the highest hotel rewards bookings as a percentage of overall customer base, so we see some some customer base who love these programs in Asia Pacific regions. But in general, the variable economics look good, and we will continue aggressively on these programs a go forward basis. The other reminder that I will put forth is that the points cost that we take our upfront the benefits from these loyalty programs are trailing benefits, so to speak, because we get the repeat benefits you get the channel benefits down the line so as where growing these number basis typically were paying an upfront cost and we're building up a pretty substantial asset. We think this is a great competitive that we're building around our brands, and we intend to keep investing behind that level.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask about Airbnb, there's been a lot of discussion about how Airbnb is impacting the hotel industry. Can you give us some color on what you're seeing in your hotel business from Airbnb and how you're thinking about that as the year goes on?
componenttext: I want to ask about Airbnb, there's been a lot of discussion about how Airbnb is impacting the hotel industry. Can you give us some color on what you're seeing in your hotel business from Airbnb and how you're thinking about that as the year goes on?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We were debating, Kevin, when we will get the Airbnb question. Listen, we are not seeing -- we don't see significant effective Airbnb on our business. I would relate the answer I would give a car. Our growth rates are substantially different from industry
componenttext: We were debating, Kevin, when we will get the Airbnb question. Listen, we are not seeing -- we don't see significant effective Airbnb on our business. I would relate the answer I would give a car. Our growth rates are substantially different from industry growth rates just because we don't see it that doesn't mean that that is not happening. We have said that Airbnb, in general, and Home Away are adding inventory in the marketplace, lodging inventory in the marketplace and is becoming more and more clear that a certain set of customers who sometimes will stay at hotels, sometimes will stay in an Airbnb or a Home Away home. So anytime you increased supply, you will put pressure on pricing. So we will -- we anticipate pressure on pricing. We do it sometimes during periods in which there's Super Bowl, let's say, or events happening in cities that use to sel lout. We have observed that it sometimes gets harder for hotels to yield up during those events and sometimes, whereas in the past, we would not have inventory for those events, we tend to have inventory for those events. So in some way, you could consider a positive as it relates to our marketplace. And then, finally, any time you have more supply, you put pressure on pricing, you as an intermediary, meaning us, want to have access to that supply. And whereas before, Home Away was part of the family, we didn't have significant access and that supply, and our goal is to build out that access to supply on our organic basis, now that Home Away's part of the family, we have access to that supply, and we will continue to build access to that supply on an organic basis. We think now that Home Away is part of the family the Airbnb effect is going to be a positive factor for us, but it's very early in kind of this evolution. And at this point, other than those circumstances when markets are kind of sold out because of big events, we're not seeing it affect our specific trends.

componenttext: It's hard to give you precise numbers around timing when you might expect to see better contribution and the rest of the world. This is a business that operates on a very quick cycle time. We invest, we see returns. When we see returns, we'll likely continue to invest I think the big change that will ultimately drive better rest of world contribution is the ultimate penetration or maturity of the U.S. business. That's an absolute huge business now for trivago, but it's still growing very strongly, and they continue to see pockets of availability to invest into the U.S. At some point over the course of the next 3 years, maybe it's this year, maybe it's 2 years from now, maybe it's 3 years from now, that market will get so big that they are fully penetrated and it does start to look from a profitability perspective anyways like their more mature markets. But at this point, it's really too difficult for us to give you color on when that's going to happen.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just want to underline what Mark was saying as far as the decision-making for the company. If you look at our technology infrastructure and our upgraded infrastructure, from a design element, we're going much more a batch data design to realtime bat
componenttext: And I just want to underline what Mark was saying as far as the decision-making for the company. If you look at our technology infrastructure and our upgraded infrastructure, from a design element, we're going much more a batch data design to realtime batch data is data comes in goes into some data warehouse analyst analyze, a decision is made, and based on the decision, you take actions real-time is a total the coming in analyzing the data on a realtime basis and you made decisions real time. And that kind of same idea that tech design idea something that we're taking to our business and we are making we don't want to be making a decision on trivago marketing investment based on something that someone put on a piece of paper as part of a nano plan because then the paper is kind of running your business. We're instrumenting our businesses as we are making the right decision tomorrow and the day after and a day after and the day after. And whatever the result is then, that's an optimized result, for real business purposes and for the purposes of our investors, then an optimized result to hit a number on a piece of paper. We take our guidance, annual guidance with you seriously, but there are a lot of different adjustments that we're making with our businesses, and we make those adjustments real time. We don't make it because he put a target on a piece of paper.
