componenttext: This is Conor on for Ken. Just to clarify, was there an FX impact disclosed for the adjusted EBITDA guidance?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Conor, there wasn't. But directionally, I could say that it is a bit more than the impact to revenue. So I'd think about it in the 600 to 700 basis point range, maybe a little bit higher.
componenttext: Yes, Conor, there wasn't. But directionally, I could say that it is a bit more than the impact to revenue. So I'd think about it in the 600 to 700 basis point range, maybe a little bit higher.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up, I guess, on an earlier question, you discussed the outlook for travel -- for leisure travel. What's the outlook for business travel in the U.S., particularly thinking in the oil country ought [ph] and in outside the U.S? Also, one thing hasn
componenttext: Following up, I guess, on an earlier question, you discussed the outlook for travel -- for leisure travel. What's the outlook for business travel in the U.S., particularly thinking in the oil country ought [ph] and in outside the U.S? Also, one thing hasn't been discussed is car rental. What do you see is the impact of Uber in the car rental business in the U.S. and Europe? And finally, just -- I kind of missed the 35%, 45% EBITDA guidance is compared with what particular number for 2015?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the corporate travel and the trends that we're seeing, listen, we're -- we've got some caution. I would say that teams are cautious about client sales in general because of the macroeconomic environment. The most clear trend that we can po
componenttext: Sure. As far as the corporate travel and the trends that we're seeing, listen, we're -- we've got some caution. I would say that teams are cautious about client sales in general because of the macroeconomic environment. The most clear trend that we can point to relating to oil prices is in terms of our business in the Nordics. As you know, we acquired VIA and integrated it into a Egencia, and we do see volumes in the Nordic regions, in general, weak, and that is very much related to oil prices being down significantly on a year-on-year basis. In general, transactions, corporate transactions look good. We're not seeing, call it, very significant spend cuts one way or the other like we saw a couple of years back. We are seeing some trading down so the revenue per transactions or gross booking per corporate transaction is down a bit, and we think that's just cautious practice from some corporations out there trading down, call it, from premium class to economy class or taking a train instead of taking a plane. But those are, I would say, on the edges. We're not seeing some big theme one way or the other as far as corporate travel changing significantly one way or the other. As far as the car rental and the impact of Uber, our car rental business is, we think, very early in its development. The volume in car days is up very significantly on a year-on-year basis, over 30% on a year-on-year basis, and most of that business is in the U.S. And we think we have a ton of potential as far as our car rental business in Europe goes. So I just think that we're on a growth path at this point that is not going to be affected by Uber. We're not going to feel kind of, call it, market numbers one way or the other just because the growth rates that we have are so high. If I were to generalize, in Q4, other trends that we saw in the car business, on the Hotwire side, we saw a higher concentration of, call it, agency bookings versus opaque bookings. We tend to make more money on opaque bookings. So that was one trend that we saw, but otherwise nothing to say, "Hey, this is Uber who's having a material effect on the business." to speak of. Mark, you want to talk to the other question?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, on the guidance, the 35% to 45% full year, year-on-year growth including HomeAway and Orbitz is in relation to the $1.165 billion in adjusted EBITDA for 2015, which is Expedia, Inc. excluding eLong.
componenttext: Yes, Michael, on the guidance, the 35% to 45% full year, year-on-year growth including HomeAway and Orbitz is in relation to the $1.165 billion in adjusted EBITDA for 2015, which is Expedia, Inc. excluding eLong.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dara, a high-level one on loyalty programs. Obviously, Hotels.com and Orbitz have pretty high profile offerings. What kind of appetite do you have for further investment behind those programs? Should these programs be expanded? Or are there other platform
componenttext: Dara, a high-level one on loyalty programs. Obviously, Hotels.com and Orbitz have pretty high profile offerings. What kind of appetite do you have for further investment behind those programs? Should these programs be expanded? Or are there other platforms in the Expedia family where you should roll further ones out?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Absolutely. I'd also add that Expedia has a pretty significant loyalty program and I think between Hotels.com, Expedia and Orbitz, we are running pretty close to 40 million loyalty members on a global basis. And I would say our appetite here is unli
componenttext: Sure. Absolutely. I'd also add that Expedia has a pretty significant loyalty program and I think between Hotels.com, Expedia and Orbitz, we are running pretty close to 40 million loyalty members on a global basis. And I would say our appetite here is unlimited. And the way to explain to that is that the variable economics behind these loyalty programs are all working. In other words, we look at the points cost, we look at the ultimate redemption value of those points, the percentage of people who are using the points -- customers who are using the points, and when to use them. And then we look at the behavior of consumers and like-for-like consumers who are in the program versus the behavior of consumers who are not in the program and how that behavior changes in terms of repeat characteristics and in terms of channel mix. When we look at those factors and compare it to the point cost, these loyalty programs work. So as long as the factors are not changing, as long as these repeat characteristics aren't changing, as long as the channel mix isn't changing, and as long as the ultimate redemption value isn't changing, then we will look to expand these loyalty programs as aggressively as we can on a global basis. There are some countries where the programs work really, really well. For example, we've been pleasantly surprised in the Asia Pacific regions where loyalty has really taken off and for example, on a Welcome Rewards basis, it's got the highest penetration of, call it, welcome rewards -- or hotel rewards, excuse me. It's got the highest penetration of hotel rewards bookings as a percentage of the overall customer base. So we see some customer bases who love these programs in the Asia Pacific regions. But in general, the variable economics look good, and we will continue to invest aggressively in these loyalty programs on a go forward basis. The other reminder that I would put forth is that the points costs that we take are upfront. The benefits from these loyalty programs are trailing benefits, so to speak because you get the repeat benefits, you get the channel benefits down the line. So as we're growing these member bases, typically we're paying an upfront cost and we're building out a pretty substantial asset. We think this is a great competitive moat that we're building around our brands, and we intend to keep investing behind that moat.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about Airbnb, there's been a lot of discussion about how Airbnb is impacting the hotel industry. Can you give us some color on what you're seeing in your hotel business from Airbnb and how you're thinking about that as the year goes on?
componenttext: I wanted to ask about Airbnb, there's been a lot of discussion about how Airbnb is impacting the hotel industry. Can you give us some color on what you're seeing in your hotel business from Airbnb and how you're thinking about that as the year goes on?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We were debating, Kevin, when we would get the Airbnb question, so thank you very much for that. Listen, we're not seeing -- we don't see significant effect of Airbnb on our business. I would relate it to the answer I gave with car. Our growth rates are s
componenttext: We were debating, Kevin, when we would get the Airbnb question, so thank you very much for that. Listen, we're not seeing -- we don't see significant effect of Airbnb on our business. I would relate it to the answer I gave with car. Our growth rates are substantially different from industry growth rates. So just because we don't see it, it doesn't mean that it's not happening. We have said that Airbnb, in general, and HomeAway are adding inventory in the marketplace, lodging inventory in the marketplace and it's becoming more and more clear that there's a certain set of customers who sometimes will stay at a hotel, sometimes will stay in an Airbnb or a HomeAway home. So anytime you increase supply, you will put pressure on pricing. So we will -- we anticipate pressure on pricing. We do it sometimes during periods in which there's a Super Bowl, let's say, or events happening in cities that used to sell out. We have observed that it sometimes gets harder for hotels to yield up during those events and sometimes, whereas in the past, we would not have inventory for those events, we tend to have inventory for those events. So in some way, you could consider it a positive as it relates to our marketplace. And then finally, anytime you have more supply, you put pressure on pricing, you, as an intermediary, meaning us, want to have access to that supply. And whereas before HomeAway was part of the family, we didn't have significant access to that supply, and our goal was to build out that access to supply on an organic basis, now that HomeAway's part of the family, we have access to that supply, and we will continue to build access to that supply on an organic basis. So we think now that HomeAway's part of the family, the Airbnb effect is going to be a positive factor for us. But it's very early in kind of this evolution. And at this point, other than those spot circumstances when markets are kind of sold out because of big events, we're not seeing it affect our specific trends.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Justin Patterson with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll go next to Justin Patterson with Raymond James.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to touch on trivago. Appreciated the disclosures you gave earlier on the call on the mature markets versus the rest of the world. Could you talk about just how you're thinking of reinvesting in the rest of the world and when we should see that
componenttext: Just wanted to touch on trivago. Appreciated the disclosures you gave earlier on the call on the mature markets versus the rest of the world. Could you talk about just how you're thinking of reinvesting in the rest of the world and when we should see that growth rate start creeping up to the contribution margin of the mature markets?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Justin. Listen, it's hard to give you precise numbers around timing of when we might expect to see better contribution in the rest of the world. This is a business that operates on a very quick cycle time. We invest, we see returns. When we see retu
componenttext: Sure, Justin. Listen, it's hard to give you precise numbers around timing of when we might expect to see better contribution in the rest of the world. This is a business that operates on a very quick cycle time. We invest, we see returns. When we see returns we like, we continue to invest. I think the big change that will ultimately drive better rest of world contribution is the ultimate penetration or maturity of the U.S. business. That's an absolutely huge business now for trivago, but it's still growing very strongly, and they continue to see pockets of availability to invest into the U.S. At some point, over the course of the next 3 years, maybe it's this year, maybe it's 2 years from now, maybe it's 3 years from now, that market will get so big that they are fully penetrated and it does start to look, from a profitability perspective anyways, like their more mature markets. But at this point, it's really too difficult for us to give you color on when that's going to happen.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just want to underline what Mark was saying as far as the decision-making for the company. If you look at our technology infrastructure and our upgraded Intertech [ph] infrastructure, from a design element, we're going from much more of a, call it,
componenttext: And I just want to underline what Mark was saying as far as the decision-making for the company. If you look at our technology infrastructure and our upgraded Intertech [ph] infrastructure, from a design element, we're going from much more of a, call it, batch data design to real-time design. Batch data is, data comes in, goes into some data warehouse, analysts come and analyze it, a decision is made, and based on that decision, you take actions. Real time is, there's a total flow of data coming in. You're analyzing the data on a real-time basis and you make decisions real time. And that kind of same idea, that tech design idea is something that we're taking to our business, and we are making -- we don't want to be making a decision on trivago marketing investment based on something that someone put on a piece of paper as part of an annual plan. Because then the paper is kind of running your business. We're instrumenting our businesses so that we are making the right decision tomorrow and the day after and the day after and the day after. And whatever the result is then, that's an optimized result for real business purposes and for the purposes of our investors, than an optimized result to hit a number on a piece of paper. We take our guidance, annual guidance with you seriously, but there are a lot of different adjustments that we're making with our businesses, and we make those adjustments real time. We don't make it because someone put a target on a piece of paper.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Dan Wasiolek with Morningstar.
componenttext: We'll go next to Dan Wasiolek with Morningstar.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering what percent of your total bookings are coming via direct and maybe how that's trended over the last year and any commentary on how you might view that trending over the next few years?
componenttext: Just wondering what percent of your total bookings are coming via direct and maybe how that's trended over the last year and any commentary on how you might view that trending over the next few years?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Carefully guarded information, but I'll give you some directional color on it. One is that, obviously, as we have built these big loyalty programs, both at Hotels.com and at Brand Expedia, and certainly, Orbitz has had this benefit as well with their
componenttext: Yes. Carefully guarded information, but I'll give you some directional color on it. One is that, obviously, as we have built these big loyalty programs, both at Hotels.com and at Brand Expedia, and certainly, Orbitz has had this benefit as well with their Orbucks program, you do build on your direct business. That's one of the core strategies of having those loyalty programs. So as those programs mature and they are getting big, we do see an increasing amount of our bookings coming direct. So that's the first point I'd make. Secondly, is in our mature markets like the U.S., we do see a significant amount of our business coming to us direct, direct type-in, responding to email, using the app, for example. And in less mature markets where we don't have establishment, the vast majority of traffic actually comes to us from variable channels, and the goal is, over time, and we do this as we enter new markets and as they mature over time, is to acquire these new customers and have them turn into repeat customers and build a business in places like Vietnam and Korea, for example, that look a lot like the U.S. I think Dara had made some comments over the course of the last couple of quarter calls that one of the trends that we have seen is that the growth rates of our direct channels and the growth rates of bookings from our indirect or variable marketing channels were starting to get closer together, and I think that's a trend that we had continued to see, and we're hopeful that's something that can continue over a long period of time as we build these loyalty programs and as our international markets mature.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everybody. Welcome to Expedia, Inc. Financial Results Conference Call for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016. Pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okerstrom,
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everybody. Welcome to Expedia, Inc. Financial Results Conference Call for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016. Pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okerstrom, our CFO and EVP of Operations.
The following discussion, including responses to your questions, reflects management's views as of today, April 28, 2016 only. We do not undertake any obligation to update or revise this information.
As always, some of the statements made on today's call are forward-looking, typically preceded by words such as we expect, we believe, we anticipate or similar statements. Please refer to today's press release and the company's filings with the SEC for information about factors which could cause our actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements.
You'll find reconciliations of the non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures discussed today in our earnings release, which is posted on our IR website at ir.expediainc.com. I encourage you to periodically visit our Investor Relations site for important content, including today's earnings release.
As a reminder, we sold our 62.4% ownership stake in eLong on May 22, 2015, which was previously a consolidated entity of Expedia, Inc. For GAAP accounting purposes, the results of eLong are included in our results through the date of that sale. In order to allow investors to compare our current results on like-for-like basis with our historical results, the commentary in the earnings release and on this call is principally focused on our earnings -- results excluding eLong, which should be considered in addition to the GAAP results on a fully consolidated basis.
Finally, unless otherwise stated, all references to cost of revenue, selling and marketing expense, general and administrative expense, and technology and content expense, also exclude stock-based compensation and depreciation expense. And all comparisons on this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2015.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Dara.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. We're off to a solid start in 2016 with our financial performance coming in a bit better than expected pretty much across the board. This was underscored by continued strong momentum in unit growth with global room nights up 37%, air tickets
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. We're off to a solid start in 2016 with our financial performance coming in a bit better than expected pretty much across the board. This was underscored by continued strong momentum in unit growth with global room nights up 37%, air tickets up 52%, carnies up 48% and advertising in media revenue growing 44%. 
Results were strong Q1 across all of our major brands, resulting and organic room night growth of 24% consistent with last quarter despite about a 500 basis point harder comp. Brand Expedia and Hotels.com each saw healthy room night growth across all regions with Hotels.com accelerating in Q1 versus Q4. Expedia Affiliate Network delivered room night growth above 30% for the fourth consecutive quarter, continuing to gain share versus our competition. And Egencia transaction growth accelerated in Q1 compared to Q4, although we saw signs of corporate travel spend tightening in the form of lower average booking values per transaction. 
Going forward through 2016, we expect overall room night growth to moderate due to harder comps in the large numbers, largely offset by decreasing headwinds on revenue per room night. 
The Orbitz integration is going well with Orbitz.com and Cheap Tickets now in the brand Expedia platform. We're particularly please with hotel conversion and room night production on both websites, which are benefiting from the upgraded technology platform, along with the depth and breadth of our hotel inventory. We've completed the move of Hotel Club traffic in customers over the Hotels.com, and we expect the ebookers migration to be complete this summer. 
Integration efforts for Orbitz business and Orbitz Partner Network are on track and will take us through 2016 and beyond in certain cases. Today, we announced some significant changes at HomeAway, as we continue to accelerate the transition of our platform from advertising to transactions. 
In the U.S, we're moving to a single and simple subscription model of $349 annually for listings that are online bookable and $499 for those that aren't. This will allow us to begin to optimize to certain of properties consumer see by matching their unique travel preferences with the right listings, while driving booking volume for owner and manager community. 
With book transaction revenue up 170% year-over-year in the quarter, we took the opportunity to more than double our direct marketing investment in order to drive more traffic to our sites and partners, while also offsetting some weakness of that we're seeing in SEL -- Google SEO volumes for some of our brands. This model changes and marketing increases, along with investments in product and technology talent, will pave the way for an improved strategic and operational footprint in a category that's becoming more and more popular with travelers all around the world. 
We're also seeing encouraging volume trends in the alternative lodging category for Brand Expedia and Hotels.com, which bodes well for future state when we fully interweaves of supply and demand across all product categories within our global bludgeon marketplaces. 
Lastly, trivago is off to a terrific start in 2016. With stand-alone revenue of $176 million, up 48% year-over-year. trivago's core European markets grew revenue of 33% on a euro denominated basis and acceleration from the 20% we saw in 2015. While the top line for the rest of the world grew 69%. The team continues to refine and improve its marketing methods and product in a way that not only benefits advertisers, but should also improved trivago monetization and margins over the long term. Now I'll turn it over to Mark on the financials.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dara. We are pleased with the results of this quarter that were a bit better than we expected. We saw solid execution across the board and also benefited from some timing differences. Easter shifted into the first quarter this year, and we will al
componenttext:
Thanks, Dara. We are pleased with the results of this quarter that were a bit better than we expected. We saw solid execution across the board and also benefited from some timing differences. Easter shifted into the first quarter this year, and we will also differed some marketing spend planned for Q1 into Q2. 
Together, we estimate these factors shifted just over $20 million of adjusted EBITDA into the first quarter from the second quarter. Organic unit growth rates across our core brands were again healthy. And of a consolidated basis, the addition of Orbitz and HomeAway, along with the final quarter of inorganic contribution from the consolidation of the AirAsia Expedia joint venture, boosted total growth rates. 
In total, excluding eLong, adjusted EBITDA was up 31% year-over-year in Q1. Orbitz and HomeAway together contributed 35 percentage points or $44 million of growth. In line with the usual seasonality of our business, adjusted EBITDA for the rest of Expedia, Inc. was down 4% collectively, as our brands put marketing spend to work and incurred other variable costs to drive bookings ahead of the other travel season and for which revenue will be recognized in future quarters. 
The anticipated acceleration and the growth rate of technology and content expense did in fact materialized and was also a factor impacting the bottom line growth rate. 
In terms of product line performance, hotel revenue growth at 25% was driven by room night growth of 37%, partially offset by a decrease in revenue per room night of nearly 9%. Acquisitions added 13 percentage points of room night growth resulting in organic growth consistent with last quarter. The GAAP between an ADR decline of just over 3% and the decrease in revenue per room night was about 540 basis points and consistent with that of the fourth quarter. 
Ongoing reductions to our contracted hotel commission rates around the world, which are aimed at expanding the breadth of our global lodging inventory and the impact of our fast-growing and successful loyalty programs, continue to be the main drivers here. 
We continue to see solid performance in both our air and car products as well. Air revenue grew 54% year-over-year on 52% volume growth. Car revenue was up 39% on 48% growth in car days, partially offset by a 6% decline in revenue per day. Orbitz added about 34 percentage points and 27 percentage points to air and car volume growth, respectively. Added media revenue was up 44% year-over-year in Q1, driven by strong performance at trivago and good growth from our Media Solutions group. 
Orbitz added about 4 percentage points of total added media revenue growth. The overall shape of our P&L this quarter was generally consistent with our ongoing goal of using leverage into the expense categories to fund aggressive selling and marketing investments around the world. As I mentioned earlier, technology and content expense was an exception in Q1, growing quite a bit faster than recent trends on an organic basis. This faster rate of organic growth was driven by trivago, our e-commerce platform group and Brand Expedia, along with increased data center cost. 
Note that we continue to incur additional cost in our core business to support the integration of the Orbitz brands. Additionally, we were pleased to be able to fill a number of open technology roles in the core business with a talented teams from Orbitz as they are rolled off their Orbitz duties. This is a great outcome for the strategic an operational standpoint but did decelerate overall hiring into Q1, which otherwise would have occurred on a more metered basis throughout the year. Note that all of this is within our previously communicated expectations for our 2016 would likely play out, and we expect to see these elevated levels of tech and content expense growth through Q3 with growth in the fourth quarter moderating. 
Against the backdrop of a strong start to the year, I do want to remind you that we continue to strike a balance between delivery and healthy near term profit while also investing to position the business for continued medium and long-term growth. In that regard, when we our performance or wind falls, either from our organic business or from acquisitions, we have a biased to reinvest at least a portion of that back into the business. This is part of the reason that we do not guide to your place undue emphasis on one specific quarter's performance, and in this quarter is no exception. 
Turning to our financials expectations for 2016. We are reiterating the guidance we gave to you on our Q4 call. On a consolidated basis, including all of the businesses we own today and excluding eLong, we continue to expect full year adjusted EBITDA to grow in the range of 35% to 45% year-over-year. Included in that growth, we continue to expect that Orbitz and HomeAway combined will deliver adjusted EBITDA of $275 million to $325 million. 
I would also like to remind you about the relative shape of our year despite the strong Q1, we do expect to the vast majority of our adjusted EBITDA dollar growth will come in the back half of the year. And I would remind folks that certain tailwinds in Q1, such as the Easter shift, will be headwinds for Q2. 
As such, I would encourage you to take a close look at quarterly phasing with our Q1 beat largely unchanged first half guidance and completely unchanged full year guidance in mind. The usual seasonality of the organic business will be amplified by recent acquisitions with integration and transition investments for both Orbitz and HomeAway in the first half of the year expected to make way for synergy realization in the second half. 
Finally, in terms of capital allocation. We are pleased to repurchase 2.9 million shares for $312 million so far this year. We will continue to balance capital allocation between M&A, share repurchases and our dividend. Now let me hand it back to Dara for a few last comments and then we'll take your questions.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Just a few closing comments to frame where we are the bigger picture before moving to Q&A. Over the past several years, we positioned Expedia, Inc. to be the most comprehensive travel distribution platform that the world has ever seen. We've
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. Just a few closing comments to frame where we are the bigger picture before moving to Q&A. Over the past several years, we positioned Expedia, Inc. to be the most comprehensive travel distribution platform that the world has ever seen. We've organically built unrivaled geographic reach and awareness for our flagship brands, Expedia and Hotels.com. We've invested billions of dollars in our technology platforms and established Expedia Inc. at the forefront of product and technology innovation in the travel industry, an advantage we'll continue to press for years to come. 
Like many industry disruptors, we've not only invested to creating all that would superior price transparency selection, ease-of-use and value for our travelers, but we've always been systematically reducing the cost of distribution for our travel supply partners. 
Lastly, with the additions of trivago, Travelocity, Orbitz and most recently, HomeAway, we've deployed capital to not only make ourselves strategically complete, but more broadly, to set up the opportunity for significant shareholder value creation over the coming years. 
Our teams are motivated, excited and hungry. And if we do our jobs, that you'll be very happy shareholders. All of us here at Expedia are absolutely up for the challenge and the journey. We hope you are too. 
With that, let's move to Q&A. Operator, will you remind participants how to queue up?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, please. First, an alternative accommodations you mentioned that as a promising there. Can you talk about build bit of the operational challenges that would allow -- that Expedia has to overcome? Do you think about it more as inventory, mark
componenttext: Two questions, please. First, an alternative accommodations you mentioned that as a promising there. Can you talk about build bit of the operational challenges that would allow -- that Expedia has to overcome? Do you think about it more as inventory, marketing, user interface, just talk about the talk about how through that frock our large market and secondly? You make this comment about to the kind of moving away from organic search. Is that a reasonably way to think about how you're thinking about marketing in the future it seems like with Google is that is kind of force people away from it'd probably places him of your competencies but just talk about the balance of organic participate for your business going forward.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as the -- thanks for the question, Mark. As far as alternative accommodations and the challenges there go, we're trying to actually not think too many big thoughts here. The main activity is behind HomeAway. And the HomeAway team has incredibl
componenttext:
Yes, as far as the -- thanks for the question, Mark. As far as alternative accommodations and the challenges there go, we're trying to actually not think too many big thoughts here. The main activity is behind HomeAway. And the HomeAway team has incredible knowledge of the homeowners and managers and what they need, and it's built up an incredible tool set there. And we want to combine that knowledge with the kind of knowledge that we have on the Hotels.com and Expedia side as far as what travelers want. And when you combine those 2, you can greater pretty powerful platform. We've obviously, done on Expedia and Hotels.com side, so we know what has to happen. And right now, the HomeAway team is heads down and really building up the infrastructure that you need in order to build a global transactional travel platform. 
And it's a bunch of technical work being done, design being -- work being done. But we've done it before. And actually, we have -- the HomeAway opportunity is so attractive that a fair bit of talent from the Expedia teams are -- have moved over to the HomeAway teams to help out one. And also because they features an enormous opportunity. So that is really is just the today execution of the HomeAway front. And then I think, on the hotels and Expedia front, once we get the HomeAway inventory, a higher percentage of the HomeAway inventory online bookable, once we feed it into Hotels.com and Expedia and Orbitz and Travelocity in an integrated manner, all signs point to that inventory producing very well. 
We have been adding some apartment inventory mostly in urban centers, et cetera, on Expedia and Hotels.com, and it is producing, and it's producing very well. And it's clearly kind of an inventory category that our users want. 
As to your search question. We are seeing some of the moves, I'd say, broadly from Google for example, there adding a fourth page search link move a higher proportion of traffic from free to paid. Fortunately, we are a company that has built up some pretty strong capabilities on the paid search side. So we're able to kind of being in the volume anyway. It is probably a net headwind for us on the margin side. But this is a headwind that we've been living with for a number of years. And it's a headwind that we've been able to grow through. And so its nothing new. We've seen this kind of -- we've heard this song before and we're up for the dance.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: Two questions, maybe one for Dara. How has HomeAway gone since you've added the booking fee? How has that affected looking growth? And what are you seeing there? There maybe talk about by brand or what really has to happen to make those EBITDA numbers work out? Maybe you can talk about the synergies and other things.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start with HomeAway. Listen, the results that we've seen, the early results of the booking fee, as you know, we launched a booking fee a bit in there that we had anticipated. The early results have been excellent and transactional booking growth
componenttext: Yes, I'll start with HomeAway. Listen, the results that we've seen, the early results of the booking fee, as you know, we launched a booking fee a bit in there that we had anticipated. The early results have been excellent and transactional booking growth is up very big, 170%. And that will be revenue that we recognize kind of down the pike in Q2, Q3 based on the state. So you don't see the revenue coming yet. But we're very, very optimistic. Conversion in general has held up very well, actually better than we had planned. Listings growth is actually very healthy and certainly healthy compared to historical trends. And we are taking a very significant portion of our services of revenue and putting it either back to customers. So for example, with the guarantee or we are putting it in marketing money to make sure that we're driving traffic growth on a global basis. So I'd say, at this point, while there's certainly going to be some questions for homeowners and the community, et cetera, I think the HomeAway team is executing very, very well in the plan. We still have a long way to go, but so far, so good.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Justin, on your question around -- I think you're really giving out why the backend loading and how aggressive is the ramp. So we feel pretty good about it. And one of the reasons we feel pretty good about it is it's largely a cost story, which
componenttext: And then, Justin, on your question around -- I think you're really giving out why the backend loading and how aggressive is the ramp. So we feel pretty good about it. And one of the reasons we feel pretty good about it is it's largely a cost story, which is we've got some pretty modest expectations on the top line and the organic business. Comps are going to get harder there. We're not expect seeing anything herculean. And really, what we're doing over the back part of this year is a couple of things. One is that we are going to see a ramp-up at HomeAway with the traveler fee, and that's just going to build as of the year goes on. We feel good about that. We already see progress. On Orbitz, we are getting that business onto the Expedia platform. We've already got Orbitz and Cheap Tickets on. The rest will come through most of this year with a few laggards. And once we get those businesses on, then we can start to shave off some of the excess cost that we've had in the first part of the year. So that's a cost story. And then, old also just go back and revisit some of the one-timers that we had in Q3. And then also, particularly in Q4, if you recall, we had some very significant purchase accounting impacts from Orbitz. We had some purchase impacts from HomeAway. And then in both cases, pretty significant deal in the integration costs in Q3 and Q4 that just aren't going to repeat themselves. So again, we feel pretty good about. It's a cost story. And we think it's very much achievable.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. Dara, can you maybe, Mark, can quantify it. Can you just talk about Europe and any impact from the parcel spot you saw anything your business? And then on trivago's performance, the business in the core European market accelerated.
componenttext: A couple of questions. Dara, can you maybe, Mark, can quantify it. Can you just talk about Europe and any impact from the parcel spot you saw anything your business? And then on trivago's performance, the business in the core European market accelerated. What was driving that?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with respect to Brussels, any time something like this happens, and we hope never to see it, but it does happen from time to time, we do see an impact to the precise area that was challenged. And certainly, we saw that with Brussels in the form o
componenttext: Sure. So with respect to Brussels, any time something like this happens, and we hope never to see it, but it does happen from time to time, we do see an impact to the precise area that was challenged. And certainly, we saw that with Brussels in the form of higher cancellation rates, certainly, lower bookings into that region. Because we're such a big global business, though, on an overall basis, there is really no meaningful impact from the Brussels attack as far as we can see. And this was very different from paris. When the Paris attacks happen, what we saw was an overall tone of fear that not only hit Paris, but also had a number of other major international centers. We didn't see a similar thing with Brussels. And of course, Brussels as a destination is just significantly smaller than Paris. With respect to trivago, sorry, not as big as Paris, yes. With respect to trivago, the business is just performing really well. One of the things to keep in mind when you're looking at the reported results is that foreign exchange is a big impact for on trivago. That eased significantly this quarter. But FX neutral, it did accelerate. And I'll just put it down to just strong execution. The business is doing well. They've been tuning their algorithms and really getting their marketplace tuned to ,atching what's best for the consumer, what's best to monetize for them, and it's working.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think just the one possibility. While we haven't exactly pulled this out, you can imagine at the core trivago markets had much more in effect as a result of the Paris attacks in Q4, which obviously, we didn't feel as much this year.
componenttext: And I think just the one possibility. While we haven't exactly pulled this out, you can imagine at the core trivago markets had much more in effect as a result of the Paris attacks in Q4, which obviously, we didn't feel as much this year.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then a quick follow-up. On the accelerator, can you provide us any kind of update there, how extensively it has been rolled out? And what's the response that you're seeing from the hoteliers?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's very early. The rollout has happened on a global basis. We've got thousands of hotels not participating in the accelerator program and the number increases on a weekly basis. I would remind you that a hotel can't just bid up with accelerator rea
componenttext: Yes, it's very early. The rollout has happened on a global basis. We've got thousands of hotels not participating in the accelerator program and the number increases on a weekly basis. I would remind you that a hotel can't just bid up with accelerator really only if they don't have high quality, if they don't have great reviews, if they don't have really good conversions. So the first thing that out of what partners have to get right is the experience and to have a terrific converting site with terrific pictures. And then, really, accelerator becomes available to them as a tool. But we've seen very strong engagement. And it's been a positive both for our supply partners, as well as our consumers. So, so far, so good, but it's still early in the year.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
