And related to that, any reason why the timing or path of a business-oriented kind of synergy realization would differ from a consumer facing segment like CheapTickets?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the Egencia goes, listen, the Egencia team has consistently been executing and gaining share in the corporate travel marketplace over a number of years. This last quarter wasn't any exception. I think that 1 new factor in Egencia's growth is tha
componenttext: As far as the Egencia goes, listen, the Egencia team has consistently been executing and gaining share in the corporate travel marketplace over a number of years. This last quarter wasn't any exception. I think that 1 new factor in Egencia's growth is that it is becoming a very, very credible choice for the largest companies out there to use. So we've always been very strong in the small and medium business segment. That makes us quite attractive to our supply partners because a lot of, let's say, the big chains and some of the airlines have a hard time reaching into small and medium businesses. But as Egencia has built out a more robust toolset for CFOs on the cost side, on the care side, you'll have some very big businesses, such as P&G using its toolset. The volume goes online. Consumers love it compared to the traditional players out there. And it's a win-win. It's a cost win. It's a consumer win. And just kind of Egencia continues to march along. And you certainly see some of the pressure there. There's been a fair amount of leadership turnover in some of the competition. And the Egencia team has been together for many years and they continue to execute on a consistent basis. And I do think that the product road map, the technology road map at Egencia looks better than it ever has. And I absolutely expect the pace of innovation there to accelerate, if nothing else. As far as the Orbitz for the OPN business or Orbitz for Business to be clear. Orbitz for Business is going to be a part of Egencia, and we're going to be rolling over Orbitz for Business customers onto the Egencia platform throughout the year. We're off to a very, very good start there. The Orbitz Partner Network business is kind of a private label business. We've got some big clients such as American Express. That group is going to go into our Brand Expedia team and our EAN team or Expedia Affiliate Network based on the nature of those relationships. Those integrations take longer because they're quite -- they can be much more complex. And as a result, that integration work is going to go into kind of late this year and in some cases, even into 2017.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, I just -- I would just add too, that when you take Orbitz for Business out of the Egencia segment, we saw acceleration as well. So it wasn't just the inorganic impact. It was healthy across the board, both room nights and ticket growth accelerated
componenttext: Brian, I just -- I would just add too, that when you take Orbitz for Business out of the Egencia segment, we saw acceleration as well. So it wasn't just the inorganic impact. It was healthy across the board, both room nights and ticket growth accelerated from Q4 into Q1.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Over time, revenue generated from the HomeAway booking fee could be pretty significant obviously. And while I'm sure some of that is going to fall to the bottom line. It sounds like you plow a lot of it back into the business. Where do you investing that
componenttext: Over time, revenue generated from the HomeAway booking fee could be pretty significant obviously. And while I'm sure some of that is going to fall to the bottom line. It sounds like you plow a lot of it back into the business. Where do you investing that incremental revenue in? Is it primarily HomeAway marketing? Or is it kind of migrate into accelerating other growth initiatives for core Expedia or other segments that we may not be factoring in at this point?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say there are 3 areas. One is certainly product and technology. It's going to take some significant investments to build out a global transactional infrastructure. Second is marketing, both on the brand marketing side, but also building out a more rob
componenttext: I'd say there are 3 areas. One is certainly product and technology. It's going to take some significant investments to build out a global transactional infrastructure. Second is marketing, both on the brand marketing side, but also building out a more robust variable marketing platform. Because HomeAway was -- HomeAway revenue was much more based on subscriptions and to some extent, not related to traffic and conversions. HomeAway couldn't bid on variable channels the way that some of our other brands can. More traffic means and our conversion means, more transactions means, you can bid more on variable channels. HomeAway didn't have the that factor. And any time you bid up into variable channels, typically your margins initially are lower and then you optimize to get to a higher return place. So certainly product, certainly marketing. We are going to reinvest fair amount of the fees also to the consumer experience to make sure that they've got a great experience, to make sure that they get the home that they expect. So I'd say those are the 3 big factors. Another factor to be aware of and it's an announcement that we made today is that on a go-forward basis, we are going to simplify the subscription product, which is going to take away some of the premium tiers that we had sold previously. And that's going to be a revenue negative, which we do believe is going to be offset by transactional revenue. But we are taking some revenue out of the system, which then we have to replace through transactions.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Tom White with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go next to Tom White with Macquarie.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Intra quarter there was kind of some increased, I guess, sort of news or commentary from some of the large hotels so that kind of trying to drive more direct bookings and taking some steps trying to make their rooms and rates look more competitive versus
componenttext: Intra quarter there was kind of some increased, I guess, sort of news or commentary from some of the large hotels so that kind of trying to drive more direct bookings and taking some steps trying to make their rooms and rates look more competitive versus what is shown on the OTA sites. Maybe just kind of brief comments on whether you're seeing kind of any impact or expect any impact from that on your business. And then just a clarification on the Egencia commentary. So the transaction kind of the unit growth was strong, but tightening of booking values. I'm just curious how that has sort of related to the leisure business historically. I mean, is that kind of a leading indicator ever? Or anything we should read into maybe what might happen in the leisure space?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take that one first and then I'll turn it over to Dara. So yes, we saw strong volume growth, but we did see a reduction in average ticket prices, average daily rates. We think some of this was essentially trade down activity, particularly we s
componenttext: Yes, let me take that one first and then I'll turn it over to Dara. So yes, we saw strong volume growth, but we did see a reduction in average ticket prices, average daily rates. We think some of this was essentially trade down activity, particularly we saw this in Europe. So people are still taking trips. They're just looking for a more cost effectively to do it. We certainly do look at the corporate travel business as a leading indicator of what's happening in the overall economy. So it's something that we're watching very closely. That said, we don't see any real impact of any softening of the economy in our leisure business at this point beyond what's happening more broadly with pricing in the market.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the hotel chains driving direct bookings. Listen, I think it makes sense for any player out there, whether in the e-commerce sector or in the travel sector, to make sure that you have a balanced source of traffic and revenue. It is very early at
componenttext: As far as the hotel chains driving direct bookings. Listen, I think it makes sense for any player out there, whether in the e-commerce sector or in the travel sector, to make sure that you have a balanced source of traffic and revenue. It is very early at this point, but we're not seeing any significant effect on our volumes. What we are seeing is that the hoteliers who provide us with the best pricing, with the best inventory, are gaining share on a relative basis in the marketplace. And they gain share 2 ways. One, just directly through bookings and also remember that they also gain audience share because they're higher up in the sort order and very often consumers are kind of clicking from our results and going and checking out the hotel direct. So I think the players who are giving us the best inventory are gaining both booking share and audience share within our marketplace. Our marketplace has been a marketplace that has been growing within the overall travel market. We have been gaining share for many years. I don't see that changing and the volume trends at this point don't suggest that that's changing. So listen, every player's going to make their own decision. And I think that the supply partners, who play well with us, who really provide a terrific experience for our customers over a long period of time, are going to gain share on our marketplace. And we'll build a terrific partnership together over the long term.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple on HomeAway. First, just it looks like some of the changes you're not going to enforce the online bookability with one of the new subscription plans. And then, it looks like you're adopting almost an accelerator model for HomeAway. So hoping you
componenttext: A couple on HomeAway. First, just it looks like some of the changes you're not going to enforce the online bookability with one of the new subscription plans. And then, it looks like you're adopting almost an accelerator model for HomeAway. So hoping you can comment on the philosophy behind those 2 changes. And then second question on HomeAway, if I can. There's been some speculation in the industry that some of the changes in traffic have been the result of just SEO snafus at HomeAway blocking Google from crawling parts of the site, suggesting that when they're fixed, some of the traffic could come back quickly. But wondering if you can just give us some clarity and what some of those issues might be on the SEO side, how permanent are they internal kind of self-inflicted versus Google-driven?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, absolutely. As far as HomeAway and the philosophy there goes is, listen, we want to create a marketplace that is flexible, but also provides right incentives. And what's very, very clear as it relates to travelers is that, they want and like online
componenttext: Sure, absolutely. As far as HomeAway and the philosophy there goes is, listen, we want to create a marketplace that is flexible, but also provides right incentives. And what's very, very clear as it relates to travelers is that, they want and like online booking. So the subscription price for one of our partners, who is providing online bookings, is significantly lower than someone who is not online bookable, so to speak. And we think that kind of provides right incentives in order to create a healthy marketplace that works for both sides. From a philosophical standpoint, we do want to build out toolsets that allow our supply partners, and this is at Expedia or Hotels.com or HomeAway, to have a very low entry base price. And then, to be able to pay, when they need a bit demand or when they want the demand. It's a very flexible model. It's easy to get into the marketplace. And then, if you want to optimize to the marketplace, you can absolutely optimize to it. And those are tools that we built on Expedia and Hotels.com side and those are tools that we anticipate building out with HomeAway as well. And HomeAway being part of our family definitely gives us an advantage there because we've done it before. On the SEO side, I don't want to get into too many specifics. There are some SEO effects that are structural such as, in general, some of the search results being moved down the page or the free search results being moved down the page. Some of the SEO results are results that we can optimize around and we can kind of build technology around. So I would say that the HomeAway team is definitely not standing still, and we're hoping to improve the SEO trends. In the meantime, though, our direct traffic trends are super, super strong and the team is more than making up for it.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Ken Sena with Evercore.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ken Sena with Evercore.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned for HomeAway that you're doing more in the way of moving from an ad model to something more transactional and subscription based. We're certainly seen through TripAdvisor and through Google where more is being done in the case of log-in a
componenttext: So you mentioned for HomeAway that you're doing more in the way of moving from an ad model to something more transactional and subscription based. We're certainly seen through TripAdvisor and through Google where more is being done in the case of log-in and also assisted booking capability. trivago had a great performance, but could you maybe walk us through how you see that platform over time and whether or not you might see more there too in a way of log-in and assisted booking, instant book and so forth?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the trivago side, listen, the trivago team is very focused on what they're good at and very focused on kind of providing the ideal hotel for the consumer in the best way. And so they are -- I think the core of trivago, which is find the ri
componenttext: Yes, I think on the trivago side, listen, the trivago team is very focused on what they're good at and very focused on kind of providing the ideal hotel for the consumer in the best way. And so they are -- I think the core of trivago, which is find the right hotel for you at the very best price, is a great, great proposition and clearly one that's working on a global basis. trivago visits in -- are up 70% on a year-on-year basis. I mean, the business and the brands are growing incredibly fast. The trivago team is experimenting with assisted booking capability. They're testing it in Europe. We -- based on the test, we expected to expand. I would say that the approach for trivago has been one in which it's not about keeping the consumer on the site, it's about optimizing the consumer experience based on however the consumer wants to book. If the consumer wants to stay on trivago, they can. If they want to go to a partner site, if they want to go to Booking.com or if they want to go to Hotels.com or Expedia, they can. So it's much -- it's very customer-focused. And I really commend the trivago team to -- for they're always solving for the consumer first. And we'll see how the results go. They're very data-driven. But we do expect this booking capability to expand on a meter basis over the year.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just maybe, if I could, just one quick follow-up. Organic room night growth for domestic and international, any chance you'd be providing that?
componenttext: And just maybe, if I could, just one quick follow-up. Organic room night growth for domestic and international, any chance you'd be providing that?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're not going to do that on this call.
componenttext: No, we're not going to do that on this call.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think -- we'll do whatever we've done in the past.
componenttext: Yes, I don't think -- we'll do whatever we've done in the past.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ron Josey with JMP Securities.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ron Josey with JMP Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a little bit about Orbitz. And I think you mentioned Orbitz.com and CheapTickets have been migrate over and those sites now have 130,000 more hotels to users. And you also said you were pleased with more improved conversion of hotels and r
componenttext: I wanted to ask a little bit about Orbitz. And I think you mentioned Orbitz.com and CheapTickets have been migrate over and those sites now have 130,000 more hotels to users. And you also said you were pleased with more improved conversion of hotels and room nights. So can you talk about the speed at which you saw those conversion rates improved? And I believe, just to confirm, are you on schedule with the overall migration onto the Expedia platform? I know you talked about 2Q and into 2017 maybe for Orbitz for Business. But I'm asking, as it relates to the synergies that you have laid out and I think "meaningfully greater" than that $75 million. So one on hotel conversions onto Orbitz and the second is just on the timeline, please.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I just say that we're very much on track. We're pleased with the conversion rates we're seeing. They're definitely in line with what we were expecting. There is a benefit from having more hotels absolutely. But we're not yet at a spot where we ar
componenttext: Sure. So I just say that we're very much on track. We're pleased with the conversion rates we're seeing. They're definitely in line with what we were expecting. There is a benefit from having more hotels absolutely. But we're not yet at a spot where we are really accelerating the growth of that business. That's something that's going to come over the course of the remainder of the year. Because one of the challenges is, we do have to get traffic growing again and we've got to get that top line moving. But we're encouraged that we do have the conversion rates to actually do that. By and large, we are on schedule. In fact, Orbitz, CheapTickets went over a little bit ahead of schedule. Ebook is on track. Hotel Club is now -- has been migrated over to Hotels.com. Many of the Orbitz for Business customers have been migrated. And the vast majority of them will be migrated over by the end of this year. The remaining piece that we'll be working on that will stretch into 2017 will be the Orbitz Partner Network. We've got some big partners, some great partners there that they have got some unique requirements. And we'll be working on transitioning those partners or alternatively, just finding the best solution for them on the host of platforms that we've got. So all in all, we're on track. And I think, again, we'd reiterate what we've said on the synergy side. $75 million was the original number. We do think we've got meaningful upside to that.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dae Lee in for Doug. My question is on TripAdvisor system booking. Could you guys kind of give us an update on the impact from the TripAdvisor system booking rollout? And whether you see any material changes from 3 months ago? And then, on -- I ha
componenttext: This is Dae Lee in for Doug. My question is on TripAdvisor system booking. Could you guys kind of give us an update on the impact from the TripAdvisor system booking rollout? And whether you see any material changes from 3 months ago? And then, on -- I have a follow-up on trivago. You guys mentioned that with the system booking rollout, trivago is becoming a bigger channel in terms of traffic volume. Is there any update on that as well?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on Trip Instant book, I'd say no meaningful change from our last call. On last call, we said, think about it in the 100 to 200 basis point impact on room night growth. Still in that range to the extent that they continue to roll out globally. And
componenttext: Sure. So on Trip Instant book, I'd say no meaningful change from our last call. On last call, we said, think about it in the 100 to 200 basis point impact on room night growth. Still in that range to the extent that they continue to roll out globally. And that other large global OTAs participate globally. It could be bigger and it could get as heavy as 200 to 300. But so far, quarter-to-quarter, we haven't seen a meaningful change from what we saw last quarter. As a reminder, from a bottom line perspective, no, we're not expecting any meaningful impact from it at all. With respect to trivago, listen, the express booking product that trivago is rolling out is still very much in the early stages, and we certainly like what we see. And we do think it's going to be a bigger channel for them in terms of volume. It's not yet at the spot where it's driving a meaningful difference for trivago. The core trivago product, the metasearch product is still driving that business. And really, there going to be a spot where they rollout instant booking at a rate that is commensurate with the consumer benefit and the advertiser benefits they see, and that's going to, we expect, transpire through the rest of this year.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, if the question was -- is trivago becoming a bigger channel for us because of trip instant book or getting less traffic from trip instant book, the short answer is, yes, because of that and also because trivago is just growing really darn fas
componenttext: And I think, if the question was -- is trivago becoming a bigger channel for us because of trip instant book or getting less traffic from trip instant book, the short answer is, yes, because of that and also because trivago is just growing really darn fast.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On HomeAway. As you remove the subscription tiers factoring in the page rankings, how do you plan to balance the individual owner being able to compete in the page ranking algorithm against the professional property managers that are using more sophistica
componenttext: On HomeAway. As you remove the subscription tiers factoring in the page rankings, how do you plan to balance the individual owner being able to compete in the page ranking algorithm against the professional property managers that are using more sophisticated software and managing multiple listings?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, listen, that's a great question. And the HomeAway team is very focused on making sure that they have a marketplace that individual owners can play in because those individual owners, those kind of [indiscernible] listings are the heart and
componenttext: Well, I think, listen, that's a great question. And the HomeAway team is very focused on making sure that they have a marketplace that individual owners can play in because those individual owners, those kind of [indiscernible] listings are the heart and soul of HomeAway. And having a marketplace where obviously, the professional PMs can operate in as well. And listen, it was true that professional PMs and individual owners were buying different tiers of subscriptions, et cetera, and they were figuring out ways to play in that marketplace. So I think that the rules of the marketplace are changing. They will be a bit more favorable to travelers and traveler preferences. So the owners who are updating their calendars, the owners who have great reviews, the owners who have terrific pictures and who put up pricing and are online bookable, will tend to get more share in our marketplace. And we'll make sure that we're making tools available for individual owners to do it. We'll make sure we've got FAQs. We'll make sure that we're in contact with them so that ultimately kind of the right product is showing up in front of the right customer. It's something that the HomeAway team thinks about a lot.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dan Powell in for Heath. Just a quick 2-part question here. First of all, with hotels going loyalty-based pricing discounts for direct booking, is there anything and any part of your guidance for the rest of the year that, that anticipates an impa
componenttext: This is Dan Powell in for Heath. Just a quick 2-part question here. First of all, with hotels going loyalty-based pricing discounts for direct booking, is there anything and any part of your guidance for the rest of the year that, that anticipates an impact from that? And then secondly, do you guys see the potential for a model where Expedia could incorporate those loyalty prices into your search results either at Expedia Brand or trivago?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as the first part of that question, is there anything our guidance? There isn't because we haven't felt any significant impact one way or the other. So our guidance is, obviously, is consistent with where we were at the beginning of the year.
componenttext: Yes, as far as the first part of that question, is there anything our guidance? There isn't because we haven't felt any significant impact one way or the other. So our guidance is, obviously, is consistent with where we were at the beginning of the year. We haven't seen any material impact. So it remains as is. Is there potential for Expedia incorporate those loyalty prices? I think absolutely. We have been working with a number of our partners, chains, regional chains, et cetera, to work on more flexible ways in which we can work with them. We're testing link-offs from our site onto the direct sites of some of our chain partners. We are willing to test promotions where we are -- where we will try to sign-up loyalty members for them. Listen, we are very big new customer acquisition channel for our partners, and we want to help our partners gain new customers. And we certainly want to arm them with whatever they need in order to bring in that customer, give them incredible service and then hopefully get a customer for life, because we don't think that one goes against the other necessarily. You've got services like TripAdvisor and trivago, who are linking off for a living and are growing incredibly well. And we are much more willing to be very flexible and in our business models. And we're finding engagements with some players out there. And I think those smart players who play with us are eventually going to gain share over long-term basis.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, the only other thing I would add is that we did mention that we are seeing some of these bigger chains that are introducing these rates lose share to independent hotels. Generally, the commission rates with our independent hotels can be slightly high
componenttext: Dan, the only other thing I would add is that we did mention that we are seeing some of these bigger chains that are introducing these rates lose share to independent hotels. Generally, the commission rates with our independent hotels can be slightly higher than the chain hotels. So far, it looks like they're often more active participants in the accelerator program. So there could be some margin benefit if we continue to see this mix shift, provided we didn't see any impact of volume, which is what the case is right now.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on HomeAway and then a follow-up. On HomeAway, you mentioned transactional booking growth up 170%. Just wondering how that compares to your internal expectations. And then secondly, you mentioned 13,000 properties added to the platform, 2
componenttext: Just a quick one on HomeAway and then a follow-up. On HomeAway, you mentioned transactional booking growth up 170%. Just wondering how that compares to your internal expectations. And then secondly, you mentioned 13,000 properties added to the platform, 23% growth. Could you talk about the sustainability of that growth rate in terms of adding supply?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the transactional booking growth, I'd say it's a bit higher than our original expectations. HomeAway is doing a bit better, and we are investing a bit more aggressively. So in general, like Mark said, we're kind of taking the overperforman
componenttext: Sure. As far as the transactional booking growth, I'd say it's a bit higher than our original expectations. HomeAway is doing a bit better, and we are investing a bit more aggressively. So in general, like Mark said, we're kind of taking the overperformance and investing it back into the business, and we think that's absolutely the right thing to do.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the metric there is transactional revenue on a booked basis. So it takes into account both the volume and the increased monetization on those bookings, just to be crystal clear.
componenttext: And the metric there is transactional revenue on a booked basis. So it takes into account both the volume and the increased monetization on those bookings, just to be crystal clear.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: At typically, we don't recognize the revenue until the stay. So there's a difference between booking and staying. And then as far as the 13,000 properties, which we added to the platform, listen, there are -- I think, on trivago, there are over 800,000 ho
componenttext: At typically, we don't recognize the revenue until the stay. So there's a difference between booking and staying. And then as far as the 13,000 properties, which we added to the platform, listen, there are -- I think, on trivago, there are over 800,000 hotels on a global basis. We're getting close to 300,000. So I think we've got a very, very long road ahead of us here.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. If I could just 1 quick follow-up. Have you said what percent of properties are now online bookable on HomeAway?
componenttext: Great. If I could just 1 quick follow-up. Have you said what percent of properties are now online bookable on HomeAway?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not said that specifically. And I will tell you that we are much more focused on driving online bookings versus trying to get every single property out there online bookable at this point. There's always going to be a tale. We haven't exactly kind
componenttext: We have not said that specifically. And I will tell you that we are much more focused on driving online bookings versus trying to get every single property out there online bookable at this point. There's always going to be a tale. We haven't exactly kind of figured out a strategy. Do we want to go 100%? Or do we want to go 90%? What we want to do is solve for kind of the heart of the business at this point, optimize it, get it transactional, get the flywheel of higher conversion, allowing you to market more, allowing you to gain more traffic, get that flywheel going. And we're not as focused on getting every single listing out there online bookable at this point. We'll determine that over the year.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That said, we did see the number of online bookable properties increase very nicely, and that's really the metric we're focused on along with the core metrics that Dara mentioned.
componenttext: That said, we did see the number of online bookable properties increase very nicely, and that's really the metric we're focused on along with the core metrics that Dara mentioned.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first on trivago. I think you guys had an option to increase your ownership stake in trivago. Can you give us an update on that? And then just a follow-up on HomeAway. Can you give us a sense of what the dollar value of online transactions is today, th
componenttext: So first on trivago. I think you guys had an option to increase your ownership stake in trivago. Can you give us an update on that? And then just a follow-up on HomeAway. Can you give us a sense of what the dollar value of online transactions is today, their run rate last year or something?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on trivago, there is an option to increase our partnership stake. There is a window of opportunity. That window is currently open. And we are in discussions with the management team there. It's just an absolutely fantastic asset. It's an absolute
componenttext: Sure. So on trivago, there is an option to increase our partnership stake. There is a window of opportunity. That window is currently open. And we are in discussions with the management team there. It's just an absolutely fantastic asset. It's an absolutely fantastic team. And at this point, we just have -- we have nothing to announce. There is an opportunity for us to buy more. There's also an opportunity for us to do nothing this time around. And we'll see which way we go here over the course of the next couple of months. In terms of the dollar value of online transactions, not a number that we're disclosing at this point.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Justin Patterson with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Justin Patterson with Raymond James.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two, please. First on HomeAway. Just as we go into the summer months here, you've obviously getting a lot of traction and getting more users to the site and have been investing aggressively here. Occupancy has been down a little bit in the hotel market. W
componenttext: Two, please. First on HomeAway. Just as we go into the summer months here, you've obviously getting a lot of traction and getting more users to the site and have been investing aggressively here. Occupancy has been down a little bit in the hotel market. We still have low gas prices. Are you seeing kind of any trading over to the HomeAway business now just base off of your understanding of how that performed last year? And then secondly, this was your biggest buyback in quite some time. Could you talk about how are you thinking about capital allocation for the course of the year? Given the market volatility, have you seen kind of bid asks come in and some of the private companies anymore?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the HomeAway side, this has been a category that has been growing for some period of time. And we look at HomeAway traffic and we look at listings counts, et cetera. And the growth rates there are consistent with the past or slightly stronger and in
componenttext: So on the HomeAway side, this has been a category that has been growing for some period of time. And we look at HomeAway traffic and we look at listings counts, et cetera. And the growth rates there are consistent with the past or slightly stronger and in some ways, is that volume that's moving from hotel to homes or is that just volume moving online. My bet is that the vast majority of that is just offline volume moving online that's powered the hotel listings for some period of time. And we think that this category is behind where hotels were. So I think it's really the move online that's driving this business at this point. But HomeAway is yound in our family. And as we observe the trends over greater period of time and especially as we bring in this inventory into Hotels.com and Expedia, I think we'll be smarter about telling you whether there are trade-offs happening or whether it's net new volume. It's just too early at this point.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on capital allocation, listen, in terms of philosophy, I'd say no change. We have always been buyers of our stock net. But of course, we're always weighing that off versus M&A and to some extent to our dividend. Last year, obviously, was a huge year o
componenttext: And on capital allocation, listen, in terms of philosophy, I'd say no change. We have always been buyers of our stock net. But of course, we're always weighing that off versus M&A and to some extent to our dividend. Last year, obviously, was a huge year on the M&A front. So we took a little bit of a break. And this quarter, we took the opportunity to get back into the market. And I'd just say, look at our past behavior, excluding 2015, is a good indicator of what's to come. In terms of private companies, yes, I think there's been more reality injected into the private markets. To be honest, we were never a company that was that interested in talking to people with the lofty valuations that were flying around for a while. So we still see opportunities around. I don't think we'll have a year as active as last year. But we're always open for business, and we -- on the M&A front, and we are -- we like the fact that valuations seem to be coming back down closer to earth.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Dan Wasiolek with Morningstar.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Dan Wasiolek with Morningstar.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the take rate in the core OTA business, it looks like this quarter the year-over-year declines lessened by a decent amount. I was wondering if you have any commentary or things to comment as far as the outlook for that take rate at some po
componenttext: Just looking at the take rate in the core OTA business, it looks like this quarter the year-over-year declines lessened by a decent amount. I was wondering if you have any commentary or things to comment as far as the outlook for that take rate at some points, maybe starting to stabilize further and potentially start to increase again on year-over-year basis.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, listen, there's a few things that went on in the quarter. I think one is that we did inject Orbitz into that core OTA segment. That actually put a little bit of pressure on take rates. And if you back that out, take rates are actually just s
componenttext: Yes, I think, listen, there's a few things that went on in the quarter. I think one is that we did inject Orbitz into that core OTA segment. That actually put a little bit of pressure on take rates. And if you back that out, take rates are actually just slightly increased. The increase was caused by a couple of things. One is Easter shifts revenue right into the quarter and there's no real bookings there. And then also, we saw a continuation of the mix shift into hotel away from air. Again, all of this excluding Orbitz. I'd say I wouldn't expect a big trend there. We're hopeful that it will stabilize over time. Certainly, as we spoken about, if you look over the next 2 or 3 years, revenue per room night declined should moderate and I think that will be a tailwind for us. But I would say for 2016, I -- there's nothing specific that I would say that it would indicate a change from what we've seen historically.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Perry Gold with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Perry Gold with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you officially reiterating the $350 million EBITDA guidance for HomeAway in 2018? Did anything about your outlook change as a result of the new subscription tiers? And then also, can you provide any color on either your app download trajectory by any
componenttext: Are you officially reiterating the $350 million EBITDA guidance for HomeAway in 2018? Did anything about your outlook change as a result of the new subscription tiers? And then also, can you provide any color on either your app download trajectory by any of your brands or any update on mobile bookings or mobile revenue as a percentage of total?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on HomeAway, we didn't officially reiterate, but I will right now. Certainly, we are happy with what we're seeing and we see no reason to change that guidance. We feel good about the progress. There's obviously lots of work ahead of us, but early encou
componenttext: So on HomeAway, we didn't officially reiterate, but I will right now. Certainly, we are happy with what we're seeing and we see no reason to change that guidance. We feel good about the progress. There's obviously lots of work ahead of us, but early encouraging signs. And the change in subscription revenue, listen, was always the plan that there would have to be some change there, and this is certainly in line with what we've been expecting.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as mobile goes, mobile penetration across our brands continues to increase. Probably last year, we were talking about it being in the 20s. Now it's in the 30s. We've got brands like Hotwire, where mobile penetration is in the 40s now. And so mo
componenttext: And as far as mobile goes, mobile penetration across our brands continues to increase. Probably last year, we were talking about it being in the 20s. Now it's in the 30s. We've got brands like Hotwire, where mobile penetration is in the 40s now. And so mobile continues to be a very, very strong growth driver for us. In general, on the app side, we don't look as much as on downloads anymore as we do into app transactions. If you're just driving for downloads, sometimes you're not focused on retention. And retention is a pretty powerful lever. And last year was an absolutely dynamite year for us as far as growth in app production, bookings, et cetera. The comps get a lot tougher this year. But app bookings continue to grow at healthy -- very, very healthy rates. It's just the comps this year are going to get a little tougher. So the teams have a bit more of a challenge ahead of them to keep those growth rates going.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there are no other questions at this time. I'd like to turn things back to our speakers for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And there are no other questions at this time. I'd like to turn things back to our speakers for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, everybody, for joining the call. Dara, any final thoughts?
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, everybody, for joining the call. Dara, any final thoughts?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd just say it's a good start to the year, but not a great start to the year. We've got a lot of work ahead of us as a team, and we're very focused. Last year was a big announcement. This year, it's a big execution year and the teams are hard at work and
componenttext: I'd just say it's a good start to the year, but not a great start to the year. We've got a lot of work ahead of us as a team, and we're very focused. Last year was a big announcement. This year, it's a big execution year and the teams are hard at work and I just want to take a moment to thank them for the work that they're putting in. It's a lot to ask and the team is coming through, and thank you for that.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everyone. That does conclude today's conference. We thank you for your participation.
componenttext: Thank you, everyone. That does conclude today's conference. We thank you for your participation.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to Expedia's Q2 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Alan Pickerill, Vice President, Investor Relations, Expedia. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to Expedia's Q2 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Alan Pickerill, Vice President, Investor Relations, Expedia. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to Expedia Inc.'s financial results conference call for the second quarter ended June 30, 2016. I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okerstrom, our CF
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to Expedia Inc.'s financial results conference call for the second quarter ended June 30, 2016. I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okerstrom, our CFO and EVP of Operations.
The following discussion, including responses to your questions, reflects management's views as of today, July 28, 2016, only. We do not undertake any obligation to update or revise this information.
As always, some of the statements made on today's call are forward-looking, typically preceded by words such as we expect, we believe, we anticipate or similar statements. Please refer to today's press release and the company's filings with the SEC for information about factors, which could cause our actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements.
You'll find reconciliations of non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures discussed today in our earnings release, which is posted on the company's IR website at ir.expediainc.com. I encourage you to periodically visit our Investor Relations site for important content, including today's earnings release.
As a reminder, we sold our 62.4% ownership stake in eLong on May 22, 2015, which was previously a consolidated entity of Expedia Inc. For GAAP accounting purposes, the results of eLong are included in our results through the date of the sale. In order to allow investors to compare our current results on a like-for-like basis with our historical results the commentary in the earnings release and on this call is principally focused on our results excluding eLong, which should be considered in addition to the GAAP results on a fully consolidated basis.
Finally, unless otherwise stated, all references to cost of revenue, selling and marketing expense, general and administrative expense and technology and content expense, also exclude stock-based compensation and depreciation expense. And all comparisons on this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2015.
With that, let me turn the call over to Dara.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. The second quarter was one on which the strength and breadth of Expedia Inc. range of businesses really shone through. Trivago continue to grow scale and gain share global travel advertising market. The HomeAway transition and the Orbitz mig
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. The second quarter was one on which the strength and breadth of Expedia Inc. range of businesses really shone through. Trivago continue to grow scale and gain share global travel advertising market. The HomeAway transition and the Orbitz migration each continue to progress well and deliver ahead of plan. Egencia continue to execute on its near-term objectives while remaining on track to deliver on sizable long-term potential. And although we delivered nice big profit objectives with adjusted EBITDA up [ph] 18% to $331 million, we did see room night growth deaccelerate more than we're satisfied with. I'll touch on each of these factors in a bit more detail.
Trivago topped $200 million in stand-alone revenue this quarter for growth of 41% or 38% currency neutral. On a trailing 12-month basis, trivago generated over $660 million of revenue and has become a leading scale player in the travel advertising space while building profitably. A little bit of perspective here. We've grown trivago revenue nearly sixfold since 2012 when we partnered out with the founding team. And today, trivago's TTM revenue is greater and growing faster than Trip Advisor's when we spun off that company. I'm sure investors are wondering about the call arrangement have in place with a trivago founders, so let me update you now. Neither Expedia nor the trivago founders exercise their option under the open put call window this year, and we instead agreed to explore the feasibility of an IPO of trivago shares with the preliminary and ambitious goal of completing the IPO before year-end. An IPO would allow investors to value trivago as a separate stand-alone company. Note that this is an IPO, not a spin-off. Expedia does not plan to sell any of our shares in IPO, and there are no guarantees than an IPO will ultimately be pursued or be successful. The put call window could reopen in March 2017 if an IPO is not completed by then. And due to legal limitations, our ability to comment further on an IPO or on future performance is extremely limited. Therefore, we'll not be updating or otherwise commenting on our outlook for trivago for this quarter or beyond or answering related questions on the call.
The HomeAway transition continues to go very well. We've now implemented the travel service fee in all major markets allowing us to increase investments in technology and product as well as marketing in order to build our brand globally. HomeAway Q2 revenue grew 36% year-on-year on a pro forma basis, driven by strength in both subscription and transactional revenue. And based on current trends, we expect revenue growth to accelerate in the second half of the year. Although this transition is not easy, we believe the pivot from classified advertising to a travel e-commerce business is a winning plan that will allow us to create better products for consumers and drive more bookings through our homeowner and property manager partners. In addition, as we move more of a HomeAway's business to online bookable, we'll be more aggressive in offering HomeAway inventory on our OTA brands, which will drive even more booking volume and will give our huge global customer base more places to stay. 
The Orbitz migration is running nicely ahead of planned time lines with Orbitz and cheap tickets and apps as well as the ebookers site and app now on the Expedia platform and the migration of the Orbitz for Business clients onto the Egencia platform complete. Although we still has a migration work to do with a number of Orbitz Partner Network customers, something that will continue into 2017, we're pleased that the heavy lifting of the Orbitz Worldwide integration is largely behind us. 
Orbitz generated a healthy $54 million in adjusted EBITDA, representing a margin of approximately 28%. Given the speed with which we've executed the integration, we're incrementally optimistic about the delivery of Orbitz-related synergies in the back half of the year. 
Now the good work on the Orbitz front did, however, come at an operational cost with the room night growth decelerating more than we planned. The wake of the Orbitz book of business combined with other recent acquisitions and organic growth in our core business strained our infrastructure and affected network quality and uptime. We've addressed the vast majority of these issues and believe that they are now largely behind us. In addition, given the shift of the team's focus towards integration, our testament philosophy was not very wanted to be and our conversion rate increases slowed on a year-on-year basis versus prior quarters. The result of this included a slowdown at the metasearch channel, not only due to continued weakness of TripAdvisor but partially due to Instant Book but also trivago where we saw our click share decrease. With the largest part of the Orbitz integration now complete, the teams are back to core execution mode with focus on regaining momentum on the conversion and marketing fronts. We're operating in a very dynamic and competitive market and are no strangers to speed bumps along the way, and we continue to expect to deliver a strong year for the company.
Now I'll turn it over to Mark on the financials.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dara. The adjusted EBITDA of $331 million that we delivered in Q2 was a solid result. From a brands perspective, we saw good results relative to our expectations on Hotels.com, Egencia, Expedia Affiliate Network and Travelocity. And as Dara mentio
componenttext:
Thanks, Dara. The adjusted EBITDA of $331 million that we delivered in Q2 was a solid result. From a brands perspective, we saw good results relative to our expectations on Hotels.com, Egencia, Expedia Affiliate Network and Travelocity. And as Dara mentioned, the profits delivered by the Orbitz brand so far in 2016 have been better than we'd expected. The HomeAway and trivago teams are also executing very well in delivering great results. Hotel revenue grew 14% in Q2 on room night growth of 20%. Orbitz contributed approximately 8 percentage points of room night growth for the quarter. In addition to the factors Dara described earlier, lower organic room night growth in Q2 compared to Q1 was also driven by the shift of Easter into the first quarter this year and a small impact from leap day in Q1, which if normalized would have reduced room night growth in Q1 by about 3 percentage points and increased Q2 by about 1 percentage point. There had been a number of terrorist attacks in recent geographies over the past months. When isolated events occur, we historically have seen an immediate reduction in bookings and an increase in cancellations the impact to destination. Typically, most of that demand gets diverted to other destinations. And over time, normal travel patterns seem to return we are hopeful to see the same patterns repeat themselves, the frequency of recent events is giving us reason to be incrementally cautious. This is something that we will continue to monitor as the year progresses. 
Average daily rates declined less than 1% in Q2, and revenue per room night decreased by about 5 percentage points. The gap between the 2 narrowed again this quarter down to 440 basis points compared to about 540 basis points in Q1. We saw a continued broad strength in other product lines with air tickets up 45% and rental car days up 36%. Note that Orbitz added 30 percentage points to ticket growth and 24 percentage points to rental car days in Q2. Our ad and media revenue grew 42% [ph] on solid performance for both trivago and our Media Solutions group. From an expense perspective, setting aside the inorganic components from HomeAway in the Orbitz, we saw leverage and cost of revenue again this quarter as the teams continue to drive efficiencies. You'll see that the year-over-year organic growth in direct and selling and marketing expenses was lower in Q2 than in Q1, partially in conjunction with the lower top line trends with variable performance-based marketing making up a large portion of this expense category. We did, however, see an elevated pace of growth in technology and content expenses as we had expected, driven by an increase in cost to support Orbitz integration efforts and growth in the core business, accelerated hiring as we brought Orbitz team members on to our Brand Expedia team early this year and expenses associated with the migration of certain functionality to the cloud. We expect the growth and technical content expense to remain elevated but to begin to moderate in the back half of the year. 
G&A expense grew a bit faster than revenue this quarter on some discrete legal and professional Note that we are expecting to see leverage and G&A expense in the back half of the year.
Turning to our financial expectations for 2016. On a consolidated basis, excluding eLong, we continue to expect full year adjusted EBITDA to grow 35% to 45% year-over-year. We do think that the contribution to full year adjusted EBITDA for Orbitz and HomeAway combined will be higher than our previous expectations with a relatively lower contribution from the rest of the business. Please note, however, that we are forecasting modestly improved organic room night growth in the back half of the year. And if that does not occur, we would likely see full year adjusted EBITDA growth closer to the lower end of the stated range. In terms of the shape of the back half of the year, I would just remind you of some discrete items that will favorably impact Q4 results. Orbitz synergies will be close to full run rate, and we'll get a the full quarter benefit from HomeAway in the fourth quarter. We will also be comping the Paris attack, significant deal-related cost and the purchase accounting impacts of deferred revenue for both Orbitz and HomeAway. 
Before closing, I do want to give a bit more color regarding the buildup of our new corporate headquarters slated to take place over the next 2 [ph] years. In March this year, we had indicated that capital outlay for the full buildout could run in the range of $1 billion to $1.2 billion. Since then, we have looked more closely at the design focus on budget and facing. And we now believe we can have the property ready for use in 2019 for something closer to half of the previous estimate. We expect to share more details as these plans are finalized. With that, let's open it up for some questions. Operator?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Kahn with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Kahn with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I got a couple of questions. So Dara, I think you touched on in the slowdown in the room night growth and how resources towards contributed to that. Can you share some more details on what exactly was affected so that we can get some [indiscernible] more
componenttext: I got a couple of questions. So Dara, I think you touched on in the slowdown in the room night growth and how resources towards contributed to that. Can you share some more details on what exactly was affected so that we can get some [indiscernible] more of a internal operational issue versus some of the competitive dynamics?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark. I'll take this one. Let me just kind of bridge you from the Q4 organic room night growth of 24% down to 12% and give you a sense of it. First of all, the time of our Q1 call, we were expecting a deceleration of somewhere between 500 and 700 bas
componenttext: It's Mark. I'll take this one. Let me just kind of bridge you from the Q4 organic room night growth of 24% down to 12% and give you a sense of it. First of all, the time of our Q1 call, we were expecting a deceleration of somewhere between 500 and 700 basis points. Majority of that was coming from Easter as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, and we were also lapping over some significant ramp up in both of the what if and Travelocity businesses. Travelocity because we've taken over control of sales and marketing after the acquisition, and what if because we have them on the platform, and then the law of large numbers, et cetera. So that is what we have exact expected. We did -- I mentioned in a few investor conferences in may that we have seen some slowdown in signals we're seeing a little bit more. And really, the majority of that incremental slowdown, we believe, is self-inflicted. There were a couple of big drivers in there. One is we did have some network and infrastructure stability issues really focused in the first half of the quarter. A lot of this was driven by just organic growth in the business. But also, as we moved the Orbitz book of business on to our network infrastructure, it wobbled a little bit, and it took us well to get the stabilize. The good news is it is now stabilized, and the team has done a great job getting that back on track. The second self-inflicted wound, if you will, was the decision that we have made really to divert the vast majority of the Brand Expedia team tech and card resources towards the integration effort and to good results. We've actually got near bits brands onto the Expedia platform faster than we had expected, and we are seeing the financial benefit of that. The cost, however, was that our test and learn velocity in terms of the rate at which we were testing a releasing new features slower on the year-on-year basis than it would have been same time last year, and that has an impact on conversion. And when you impact your conversion it impacts not only the transactions that are coming to you directly but also in variable channels. And Dara mentioned the slowdown that we were seeing in the metasearch channel. So that was really the majority of that, call it, 500 to 700 basis points of incremental slowdown beyond that, which we had expected. The rest of it, I -- it's very difficult to pinpoint. Certainly, we do remain in an intensely competitive marketplace. And any time we stop the innovation pace, we have competitors that are very quick to respond and take share, and we certainly did see that in the metasearch channels. Also, it's really hard to read in use and see what's happening in the overall geopolitical environment, particularly the terrorist attacks and the frequency of the recent terrorist attacks in Europe. And even though we can't pinpoint an overall impact exactly on that, it wouldn't surprise us if that's having some impact as well.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful. And then just to follow up on your answer, if I look at the room night growth by geography, it seems like the slowdown international room night was sort of more pronounced. Is there anything to call out there?
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful. And then just to follow up on your answer, if I look at the room night growth by geography, it seems like the slowdown international room night was sort of more pronounced. Is there anything to call out there?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, in general, the international points of sale have a higher concentration into the metasearch channels than the domestic points of sale where we have bigger brand traffic. And of course, the macro environment could be affecting international
componenttext: Yes, I think, in general, the international points of sale have a higher concentration into the metasearch channels than the domestic points of sale where we have bigger brand traffic. And of course, the macro environment could be affecting international more. The last is actually a comp issue, which is we have brought in our consolidated Brand Expedia, the joint venture with Air Asia last year same time, so just seeing a comp impact there.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Second question I had was really around the HomeAway sort of integration. I think, Dara, you talked about how we can start to offer up some of the HomeAway inventory into core Expedia. Can you talk about the timing of that and when we can start to
componenttext: Got it. Second question I had was really around the HomeAway sort of integration. I think, Dara, you talked about how we can start to offer up some of the HomeAway inventory into core Expedia. Can you talk about the timing of that and when we can start to see that?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We don't have the specific timing on it at this point on it. The whole focus for HomeAway right now is to build up the online bookable muscles. And we're really, really pleased with the progress there, over 1 million online bookable listings. Overall
componenttext: Yes. We don't have the specific timing on it at this point on it. The whole focus for HomeAway right now is to build up the online bookable muscles. And we're really, really pleased with the progress there, over 1 million online bookable listings. Overall listings growing at 20-plus percent, actually accelerating versus how fast the listings were growing there. That's the focus right now of the HomeAway team, and taking some of that revenue and reinvesting it in marketing to make sure that our homeowners and property managers get plenty of traffic. We will have more to say about distribution on Expedia and Hotels.com and all of our other brands, so stay tuned there. And I think, in general, the theme that you should look for is a much deeper integration of the HomeAway inventory on to the Expedia platforms, in general. And prior, when we worked with HomeAway as partners before, the integration was more of a link-off experience. It was a little bit of a shock for users. And this HomeAway inventory is going to be fundamental to our product on a long-term basis, so we're making the cost of investments that we have to to make sure that the integration is perfect and our clients who are online bookable and especially instant bookable get plenty more traffic the way they want that traffic.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question comes from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could give us an initial feedback on the Facebook dynamic ads that I think trivago is running for travel from Facebook and Instagram and then maybe any initial comments on your traction with the messenger bot?
componenttext: Wondering if you could give us an initial feedback on the Facebook dynamic ads that I think trivago is running for travel from Facebook and Instagram and then maybe any initial comments on your traction with the messenger bot?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as Facebook the dynamic ad go, we are experimenting and really starting to scale up with Facebook across our brands on a global basis. The spend there is now getting to real significance, and our engineering teams have been working with the Fa
componenttext: Yes. As far as Facebook the dynamic ad go, we are experimenting and really starting to scale up with Facebook across our brands on a global basis. The spend there is now getting to real significance, and our engineering teams have been working with the Facebook engineering teams in a very productive way. And basically, all of the brands are experimenting with Facebook in kind of finding veins traffic and conversion veins that are awfully interesting. So our spin is up significantly. It looks like it's working, and we think that the momentum there will continue. You certainly see it in the Facebook results. As far as the Facebook messenger bot, I think it's too early to tell. It's a promising technology. I think messaging technology, in general, whether on Facebook or other platforms, is something that we're quite interested in, both in terms of messaging itself and the platform and in terms of AI and machine learning that we can build in behind it to radically improve customer experience. So at this point, so far so good, but it's not something that we scale yet.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next will be Michael Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Next will be Michael Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the HomeAway business, how would you describe any impact that you're seeking on booking rates as a result of the booking fee based on, I guess, the results and kind of the qualitative guidance you give from answer is probably minimal And then do you be
componenttext: In the HomeAway business, how would you describe any impact that you're seeking on booking rates as a result of the booking fee based on, I guess, the results and kind of the qualitative guidance you give from answer is probably minimal And then do you believe that you're seeing any impact in either HomeAway or business from alternative or combination sites at this point?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the second one first, which is that the HomeAway results have been pretty great. So -- I mean we expected to be bringing in a really strong company, and we wrote a big check to bring in HomeAway. And I'd say, so far, the results have been bett
componenttext: I'll answer the second one first, which is that the HomeAway results have been pretty great. So -- I mean we expected to be bringing in a really strong company, and we wrote a big check to bring in HomeAway. And I'd say, so far, the results have been better than expected. So I think that this alternative lodging space is just a big space, and HomeAway is benefiting from that. And obviously, Airbnb, which is the other big player in the category, is clearly benefiting from it as well. The reaction when we did bring in the booking fees, et cetera, we did see a conversion decrease initially, but the great news is that the team, the HomeAway technology team, now they've got traffic, and they're able to optimize the site in a way that they weren't able to. So conversion is actually up on the year-on-year basis because of the optimization work because of the feature work that the teams are embarking on. And I think that, that momentum is going to continue for some period of time when we look at HomeAway conversion versus, let's say, Hotels.com or Expedia conversion and in light destinations, HomeAway conversion is far lower. So we think we've got plenty of work to do there, and we think that you got plenty of upside there. The other factor that we want to look at is subscription renewals and subscription renewal rates. And again it's -- things look good there. So I think anytime you change your model through some in the marketplace. You had to over communicate to our homeowners and our partners, but I think now we're settling down, and we can both build a great business together.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you can just attribute any of that organic slowdown in room night growth to the hotel efforts at loyalty pricing discounts and ad campaign supporting those? Are there markets where there may not be enough independent supply to backfill and ki
componenttext: Wondering if you can just attribute any of that organic slowdown in room night growth to the hotel efforts at loyalty pricing discounts and ad campaign supporting those? Are there markets where there may not be enough independent supply to backfill and kind of replace what the change you're doing? And I guess, as a follow-up to that, when you kind of take a step back and look at the magnitude of some of the discounting you're doing and you kind of listen to Marriott on their earnings call this morning talking about seeing net pressure on ADRs from what they're doing, like how do you guys think this plays out? Do they keep doing this at a net loss themselves? Or do you think, ultimately, they pull back on this perspective on that?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, it's very difficult for us to speculate as to what the Marriott's and the Hiltons of the worlds are going to do. These are really smart big companies, and they're making their own decision. I think the question that you asked about is affecting us
componenttext: Listen, it's very difficult for us to speculate as to what the Marriott's and the Hiltons of the worlds are going to do. These are really smart big companies, and they're making their own decision. I think the question that you asked about is affecting us is clearly a question that we asked ourselves because we saw slowdown in room nights, and we have 18,000 statisticians looking in every which way and every angle to see whether it's affected us. And the short answer is that we haven't seen any real correlation in our performance in chain-heavy markets versus chain-light markets. You would think that in a market that has lots of chains, you would see some conversion degradation or performance degradation to the extent that inventory is -- inventory quality is lessening, but we haven't seen any of that whatsoever. It may happen, it may not happen. But to date, we haven't seen any correlation at all. What we have seen is we have seen a shift of our bookings from some of the chains that are discounting to independents and/or chains that are not discounting. So there have been certainly a share shift and maybe that was affecting Marriott ADRs. And a share shift actually, in an interesting way, is giving us a margin upside. So from that standpoint, that does not that although, we're not necessarily managing from margin. I think the other perspective whether they're going to continue or not is we attract brand-diagnostic travelers as far as what hotel they're staying at or they're staying at. And actually, if you look at Hotels.com on a global basis, the biggest chains in the world the largest hotel chains get less than 0.5% of searches on the Hotels.com site. Just to make sure you understand that. Someone comes in Hotels.com, less than 0.5% of them are searching for specific large brand out there. So these are folks who want a great hotel in Paris, and it's a terrific opportunity for great hotels in Paris to stand up and to market themselves to someone who hasn't yet become loyal to a chain. And we have partners who are, at this point, standing up. The economy is a little bit weaker than it has been before, so we are seeing some promotional activity and discounting activity. And so far, we're satisfied with the quality of inventory. Now we'll watch this it's a big chance were marketing aggressively so as far as competitive brand marketing activity probably not good for us, but we haven't seen any direct effect as a result of their actions, and we'll work with them because we definitely want to grow with the chains. We think that's a positive way to grow volume going forward and we continue to have promising dialogue with them.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Tom White with Macquarie.
componenttext: The next question comes from Tom White with Macquarie.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to your comments about the trajectory for room night growth for the balance of the year. I heard some things about, I guess, you're kind of guiding to improvement but also comments around fears in the macro. So trying to reconcile those 2 things. And
componenttext: Just to your comments about the trajectory for room night growth for the balance of the year. I heard some things about, I guess, you're kind of guiding to improvement but also comments around fears in the macro. So trying to reconcile those 2 things. And then just on Brexit and terrorism, could you give us a bit more color on kind of what you're seeing in terms of changes in traveler behavior? Are you seeing increases in cancellation rates? Are you seeing people kind of book travel in other areas? Any kind of color you could give there would be great.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy to, Tom. With respect to the trajectory from room night growth, if you look at what I said around kind of the self-inflicted piece of what we saw in the second quarter, half of the, call it, 500 -- around the half of [ph] 500 to 700 basis poin
componenttext: Sure, happy to, Tom.
