With respect to the trajectory from room night growth, if you look at what I said around kind of the self-inflicted piece of what we saw in the second quarter, half of the, call it, 500 -- around the half of [ph] 500 to 700 basis points of decel that we have not anticipated is self-inflicted, and a chunk of that is related to the network and stability and infrastructure that we've now solved. So we are expecting through the back part of this year work our way and clawback that piece of the business that was self-inflicted, both as network infrastructure issue, also as we ramp up test and learn velocity and get year-on-year conversion improvements back. Against that, I guess, plan if you will, that we're executing against things that in our control is this backdrop of just the increasing frequency of terrorism. And to put some numbers on it, historically, we have seen these destinations that experience these types of terrible things drop, and then they pop back in a matter of weeks, if not months. But if you take France as a destination, for example, which has had just a terrible go of it, room night growth pre the most recent Paris attacks was in and around the mid-20s. After the Paris attacks, it settled out into low single digits. As soon as Brussels happened, it hit negative single digits. And since Nice, it's been down double digits, like mid-20s. So we have not seen the recovery in France. So although we're hopeful that we will see a recovery, just the pace of this has got us into unchartered territory. Now the upside of this is that we are seeing places, particular places in Spain, Ireland, et cetera, we're seeing increasing volume there. Clearly, people are shifting the places of that you're traveling to, but we're cautious that this could just put a negative tone on just on the overall, at least European, travel trends. Just to touch on Brexit quickly, which is one of the other things you mentioned, the Brexit response was similar to what we see any time you see big currency moves, and it was really currency related. As soon as the pound devalued versus the U.S. dollar, we saw bookings, particularly into London out of the U.S. increase pretty significantly. But beyond that, we haven't seen a significant impact. And I think for now, we're not expecting to see one.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Jed Kelly with Oppenheimer.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you discuss a mix of listings that are incurring the traveler fee between professionally managed property single owner units? And is one group outpacing the other in terms of overall bookings growth?
componenttext: Can you discuss a mix of listings that are incurring the traveler fee between professionally managed property single owner units? And is one group outpacing the other in terms of overall bookings growth?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say that, in general, the professional managers group is probably engaged a little more quickly. They've got a bunch of volume, and they are leaning forward into the traffic growth that HomeAway is delivering now. But we continue to work with our indi
componenttext: I'd say that, in general, the professional managers group is probably engaged a little more quickly. They've got a bunch of volume, and they are leaning forward into the traffic growth that HomeAway is delivering now. But we continue to work with our individual owners incredibly important component of our marketplace, and we see excellent progress in bringing them online and making them online bookable. So it's a process. It's a communication and education process. And I'd say, so far, so good.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And that question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple of questions. I realized that revenue and bookings aren't directly tied together, but curious if you could give us a sense of what drove revenue performance above booking growth or organic booking growth. Obviously, there's a lot of noise
componenttext: I guess a couple of questions. I realized that revenue and bookings aren't directly tied together, but curious if you could give us a sense of what drove revenue performance above booking growth or organic booking growth. Obviously, there's a lot of noise about getting commissions and other things going in the space. So curious what it was that drove that outperformance. And then on the HomeAway piece, do you have any sense of what kind of an impact, if at all, the booking fee has had on gross bookings on the side. I understand you don't report the gross booking number for HomeAway, but if you could just sort of quantify for us your best feeling for where that is.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The simple answer for the first question is both HomeAway and trivago report into revenue and not into bookings. So you've got inorganic and HomeAway dropping directly into that and Trivago organic revenue growth, obviously very strong and faster th
componenttext: Sure. The simple answer for the first question is both HomeAway and trivago report into revenue and not into bookings. So you've got inorganic and HomeAway dropping directly into that and Trivago organic revenue growth, obviously very strong and faster than the overall business with no bookings to offset. So that's the big driver. In terms of gross bookings on the side and the impact of the booking fee, we generally are seeing very strong results of their. As a reminder, we now have 1 million online bookable properties, so more transactions are coming online. We -- last quarter, we actually reported a booked transactional revenue number just to give you a sense of it. And what that represented is, essentially, the revenue that HomeAway drives from bookings that happened online on a booked basis, recognition happens on stay. That number this quarter was well north of 200% [ph] year-over-year. So we're seeing really strong results there, and we're able to actually put that increased volume and increased revenue that HomeAway has back into the business. And one of the most significant investments that HomeAway has been making is not only in product and technology to make the experience better for both owners and managers as well as consumers, but they put a significant amount of money back into sales and marketing. In fact, the first half of this year, direct sales and marketing spend, up over 80% year-over-year. So we're really creating this flywheel. And it just seems the more volume we create, the more attractive online bookability becomes -- becomes for owners and managers, and we're starting to get real traction there that we're very pleased to see.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.
componenttext: And we have a question from Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So following up on earlier question, the industry has typically argued that people will travel, particularly for leisure always, regardless. So the question is indeed is this true? Are you seeing this? And if so, where are the people going? Or put another
componenttext: So following up on earlier question, the industry has typically argued that people will travel, particularly for leisure always, regardless. So the question is indeed is this true? Are you seeing this? And if so, where are the people going? Or put another way, who in the industry are the winners currently, which is a difficult way to think of it but nonetheless....

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what I'll tell you is this is an unusual time where uncertainty and the terrorist activity that we're seeing is it seems to be happening at an unprecedented rate. Historically, whenever we've seen something happen locally, there has been a reactio
componenttext: I guess what I'll tell you is this is an unusual time where uncertainty and the terrorist activity that we're seeing is it seems to be happening at an unprecedented rate. Historically, whenever we've seen something happen locally, there has been a reaction. There'd been significant cancellations, and then you have a couple of weeks of, call it, business being running below normal. And usually, you see that the patterns of travel kind of work around the uncertainty or the interruptions. So as an example, presently, we see Spain as a destination being incredibly strong. Why is that? It's obviously because France as a destination is weak. Turkey is weak. A bunch of other summer destinations that Europeans used to travel to are down. So Spain is really strong. Now with all the activity here, is it happening on an overall effect on the travel market? I can only say maybe. We don't see it in general. Historically, we've seen travel grow at GDP plus 3% to 4%, and we've seen online travel kind of grow faster than that. We've got exposure to Asia in some markets, which kind of make our growth rate even significantly higher than the overall travel growth rate. And I'd expect more the same. There may be a general slowdown. I wouldn't predict that because we haven't seen it before. But even if there is, we think companies like ours, companies that are strong and technology and customer and brand side can grow through any kind of these interruptions.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess bottom line, are you saying locations may change and the strong will get stronger?
componenttext: So I guess bottom line, are you saying locations may change and the strong will get stronger?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, destination destination mix absolutely changes. But usually, the person who wants to go on a summer vacation goes on a summer vacation. If there's a general trend that I'd say is usually when you see periods of uncertainty, you see people staying clo
componenttext: Yes, destination destination mix absolutely changes. But usually, the person who wants to go on a summer vacation goes on a summer vacation. If there's a general trend that I'd say is usually when you see periods of uncertainty, you see people staying closer to home as opposed to going on that long trip, they're going Americans going to Europe they'll take their summer vacation in The States if there's any pattern to that. But irrelevant to that and I think a lot of other companies are relevant for that kind of service as well.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if there biggest potential losers, they will be the airlines because...
componenttext: So if there biggest potential losers, they will be the airlines because...

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's tough to tell. I think right now the airline issue is more about capacity than demand I guess the 2 were certainly related.
componenttext: No, it's tough to tell. I think right now the airline issue is more about capacity than demand I guess the 2 were certainly related.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Chris Merwin with Barclays.
componenttext: Next question will come from Chris Merwin with Barclays.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had a couple. Dara, you talked about scaling up your ad dollars in Facebook. Can you talk a bit about how the ROIs on Facebook are compare to what you're currently getting on Google, just in the relative basis now we should think about the shift in m
componenttext: Just had a couple. Dara, you talked about scaling up your ad dollars in Facebook. Can you talk a bit about how the ROIs on Facebook are compare to what you're currently getting on Google, just in the relative basis now we should think about the shift in marketing spend should impact you guys from a margin perspective in the near or long term. And then secondly, as it relates to the travel fee where Hotwire a higher margin that's going in line with your expectations now that the pricing changes been fully rolled out But at some point, does it make sense to also include online payments as part of the lower cost price option in HomeAway to maybe further accelerate the pace of the travel fee rollout?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as scaling up on the ad dollars in Facebook and ROI, that's competitive information that we won't get into, but we are working with Facebook on a kind of variable basis. We've got a bunch of data scientists looking at the return, and we would
componenttext: Sure. As far as scaling up on the ad dollars in Facebook and ROI, that's competitive information that we won't get into, but we are working with Facebook on a kind of variable basis. We've got a bunch of data scientists looking at the return, and we would not be scaling up our spend on Facebook unless it was getting us more than satisfactory results. We will look to maximize spend on an affordable basis in any variable channel, which includes Google and includes metasearch. And now more and more, it's including Facebook as well. As far as the travel fee rollout and online payments, can you explain a little bit more what you're asking about?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean just to implement, I imagine a listing doesn't only have to be online bookable but online payable and I believe and correct me if I'm wrong that people can paid a lower cost option to either listing online bookable, but it doesn't also mandat
componenttext: Sure. I mean just to implement, I imagine a listing doesn't only have to be online bookable but online payable and I believe and correct me if I'm wrong that people can paid a lower cost option to either listing online bookable, but it doesn't also mandate that its online payable, which I imagine is up prerequisite for having a travel fee.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, the 2 go together, and we are working to introduce more payment methods, online payment methods, especially on the international front, PayPal all kinds of credit cards, et cetera and are also looking to build out products like the travele
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, the 2 go together, and we are working to introduce more payment methods, online payment methods, especially on the international front, PayPal all kinds of credit cards, et cetera and are also looking to build out products like the traveler guarantee for HomeAway that can sense travelers to book essentially on system because there are some bookings obviously that go off system, which is 2 people talking to each other and writing a check and hoping that the check lands someplace. So we think that we can create a safe and cheap environment for consumers to come together with homeowners within the HomeAway platform, and we will be looking to optimize of that on a go-forward basis.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our question will come from Ronald Josey with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our question will come from Ronald Josey with JMP Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know we talked about this a little bit. But maybe on Orbitz integration, I'm wondering, Dara, what's different with integration of Orbitz versus out of Travelocity to others you've done in which you saw the disruption the core business and took your eye
componenttext: I know we talked about this a little bit. But maybe on Orbitz integration, I'm wondering, Dara, what's different with integration of Orbitz versus out of Travelocity to others you've done in which you saw the disruption the core business and took your eye off that test and learn thesis are you've been doing for sometime surprised to see that this quarter? And then bigger picture talking about HomeAway, can you talk a little bit more about where you are with adding inventory to the mix and when that might come into play?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as Orbitz goes, the Orbitz integration was fundamentally different from Travelocity. Because if you remember, Travelocity initially was a technology integration as related to that asset which was owned by Sabre. So Sabre really had to work wit
componenttext: Yes. As far as Orbitz goes, the Orbitz integration was fundamentally different from Travelocity. Because if you remember, Travelocity initially was a technology integration as related to that asset which was owned by Sabre. So Sabre really had to work with a bunch of the -- had to do with the headcount issues, the employee issues, and we just had to deal with the technology integration. Orbitz coming in was not only integrating technology but also took, kind of, the efforts of lots and lots of people across the company because we're essentially bringing the company in. So that's one. The second is that Orbitz is a number brands. It's not just Orbitz, it's a ebookers brands. We closed down Hotel Club in Asia. We are integrating the Orbitz partner network and Orbitz for Business. So it is a substantially larger and more complex integration than the Travelocity integration. And I do think that another factor is that we brought in Travelocity, we brought in What If and we brought in Orbitz, I think I don't know what the total time between those 3 integrations were, but it's 3 integrations one after the other. And I think that probably each integration maybe knocked us back by 5% or 10%. And the 5% or 10% started adding up with the last integration, the Orbitz integration being the biggest one and the challenging one. Super, super prod of the company for getting it done. We knew that it was a challenge through the second quarter, and we said let's put our heads down, get it done, so we can get back to core execution, and we're there. And expectations for us internally are high. We think that we're going to execute, we have before, and I think we will again. As far as HomeAway inventory, adding inventory to the mix, we're looking at adding inventory all over. I do think that our strengths tend to be in the resort area as far as sun destinations, mountain destinations, et cetera, but we are adding urban listings as well. And I think that as we integrate more fundamentally with Hotels.com, Expedia, Travelocity, Orbitz, the pace of urban listing acquisition is going to increase.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Harry Gold with Muffet Nathanson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Harry Gold with Muffet Nathanson.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you guys seeing any early upside from your Accelerator program at this point? Is that where ADR trajectory room night growth is coming from?
componenttext: Are you guys seeing any early upside from your Accelerator program at this point? Is that where ADR trajectory room night growth is coming from?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are seeing upside. I -- again, I think it's early. There's still a lot of training to do and a lot of behavior for hoteliers to learn, but we're seeing great uptick. I mean, we've got thousands of hotels that are actively using the tool, and we expect
componenttext: We are seeing upside. I -- again, I think it's early. There's still a lot of training to do and a lot of behavior for hoteliers to learn, but we're seeing great uptick. I mean, we've got thousands of hotels that are actively using the tool, and we expect that it's going to go up significantly from their. The hotels that use it are finding exactly what they might expect, which is they're getting incremental volume when they need it at a yield, which is attractive to them. So we're very pleased with it, and I think there's more to come. Not a big factor in the revenue per room night and ADR story at this point. The narrowing of the gap there is really largely due to the reasons that we predicted is that we are getting to the end of our margin reduction strategy here, and we are starting to see just better, better trends, and that's something we do expect to continue here over the next little while. And then the last thing that's helped that is something that Dara mentioned, which is we are seeing a mix of our business towards independent hotels that are taking advantage at our marketplace and taking advantage of, really, the less attractive pricing but in many cases some of the partners are providing to our consumers.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question is from Justin Patterson with Raymond James.
componenttext: This question is from Justin Patterson with Raymond James.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of just sales and marketing, that came in quite a bit better I think we're all expecting this quarter. And you also mentioned there were some room night growth deceleration around integration efforts but have you been able to parse out just wheth
componenttext: In terms of just sales and marketing, that came in quite a bit better I think we're all expecting this quarter. And you also mentioned there were some room night growth deceleration around integration efforts but have you been able to parse out just whether or not backing up the Accelerator on marketing expense slowed room night growth? Is there kind of a trade-off between spending for growth here that we should be thinking about? And then secondarily on Europe, you mentioned the metasearch factors being behind deceleration there as well as the macro part. Is there any changes on the meta side that you're perhaps contemplating, given those results?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the vast majority of our direct sales and marketing is variable to performance in nature. And in a sense, it's auto adjusting, which is when we have lower year-on-year conversion gains, as Dara mentioned, we have seen, particularly at Brand Exped
componenttext: Sure. So the vast majority of our direct sales and marketing is variable to performance in nature. And in a sense, it's auto adjusting, which is when we have lower year-on-year conversion gains, as Dara mentioned, we have seen, particularly at Brand Expedia. We automatically essentially adjust and pull back a little bit because we're very focused on making sure that we maintain the appropriate profitability. And that said, those channels themselves are the least profitable channels that we have. And so when we do have a slowdown in conversion, it does translate into room night growth, and the first channels to go are the ones that are most expensive. So there's a natural offsetter or a natural hedge that we see in our P&L. With respect to macro and accounts we saw at metasearch and Europe and changes, I think the biggest changes that we are very focused on getting our year-on-year test and learn velocity right back up where it should be. We are hopeful that, that will improve conversion rates. And then we will hopefully see the exact reverse of what we saw in sign the second quarter, which is room night growth accelerating back up and sales and marketing going back up with it and hopefully a little bit less than room nights.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Dan Wasiolek with MorningStar.
componenttext: Next question is from Dan Wasiolek with MorningStar.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the HomeAway brand, just wondering if you had any thoughts on the potential impact from some cities coming out and announcing maybe stricter enforcement of home share laws and how that might impact the HomeAway brand?
componenttext: Just on the HomeAway brand, just wondering if you had any thoughts on the potential impact from some cities coming out and announcing maybe stricter enforcement of home share laws and how that might impact the HomeAway brand?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think from a HomeAway standpoint, we tend to have a more significant portion of our business today in destinations that are not urban destinations and destinations that are mountain and beach destinations. And these are destinations that have had
componenttext: Well, I think from a HomeAway standpoint, we tend to have a more significant portion of our business today in destinations that are not urban destinations and destinations that are mountain and beach destinations. And these are destinations that have had this business around for a long time. These are -- the majority, the vast majority of HomeAway's business are whole homes, all HomeAway's business is whole homes, they're usually second homes. And they're usually in destinations where the home rental seasonal home rental business has been around for a long time and is a very significant contributor to local economies, et cetera. So we are watching with interest what's going on. Every single municipality is looking at this issue in a different way. We are working closely with those municipalities. And we think an end, this is a product that consumers want. It attracts travelers to destinations, travelers bring jobs, they bring money. And we think that in working with these local municipalities, ultimately, we will come up with the appropriate law to protect consumers and homeowners and the residents of those municipalities as well. This is a process that's going to take a long time, but we're in it for the long haul. And at this point, the activity that we see is affecting us less then, let's say, some of the other players out there.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That question will come from Peter Statler with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: That question will come from Peter Statler with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rob on the call for Peter. One question. Last quarter, you noted some softness, I think, in the corporate travel environment in terms of travelers trading down a bit. It seems like the business actually had a pretty nice quarter, held up quite nic
componenttext: This is Rob on the call for Peter. One question. Last quarter, you noted some softness, I think, in the corporate travel environment in terms of travelers trading down a bit. It seems like the business actually had a pretty nice quarter, held up quite nicely in terms of booking and revenue growth. I'm just wondering if you could give us an update on trends in corporate and also what helped drive the rebound there. And then a quick follow up on what you might be able to do with an update on when we might begin to see some HomeAway inventory on other Expedia's brand sites.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in corporate travel, absolutely Egencia had a great quarter. So hats off to the Egencia execution there. They did get a little bit of help from the Orbitz for Business integration, and they actually completed the migration of those clients now, a
componenttext: Sure. So in corporate travel, absolutely Egencia had a great quarter. So hats off to the Egencia execution there. They did get a little bit of help from the Orbitz for Business integration, and they actually completed the migration of those clients now, all of them onto the Egencia platform. So that was some of what you saw in the numbers, but they did have a great organic quarter. They did, however, continue to see evidence of the trade-down activity. Particularly in Europe, volume held up nicely. But in general, transaction values were down year-on-year. So there's no significant change on that front.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think just to add on Egencia, the Egencia team now, they have completed largely the acquisition and the Nordics and now Orbitz for Business as well. So they're a little many case of what we described on the Expedia front. I think the team finally ca
componenttext: And I think just to add on Egencia, the Egencia team now, they have completed largely the acquisition and the Nordics and now Orbitz for Business as well. So they're a little many case of what we described on the Expedia front. I think the team finally can look forward to really steering their attentions on innovating and building that company. And we're very excited about their position, not competitively. We've invested in their platform in technology. And if anything, we anticipate acceleration and growth for the Egencia brand in the back half of the year and especially going to next year. So we're pretty excited about that team, where they've gotten to and even more excited about where they're going. As far as HomeAway and when we might see the inventory on the core Expedia brands, no update as of now, but news upcoming.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question is from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: This question is from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jason Mitchell here for Justin. I'm just wondering if you have any updates on how you're thinking about the TripAdvisor Instant Book platform. And given all the kind of turmoil in the travel market, have you seen any impact on your bookings throug
componenttext: This is Jason Mitchell here for Justin. I'm just wondering if you have any updates on how you're thinking about the TripAdvisor Instant Book platform. And given all the kind of turmoil in the travel market, have you seen any impact on your bookings through trip? And then just kind of follow up on HomeAway, the new pricing plan for subscriptions, do you expect to change the mix of tall of properties between subscription and paper booking?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as TripAdvisor goes, no change as far as our view there. Obviously, we're not at Instant Book at this point. We think the product has improved as far as the brand representation of players who are working with Instant Book. And so we will be
componenttext: Sure. As far as TripAdvisor goes, no change as far as our view there. Obviously, we're not at Instant Book at this point. We think the product has improved as far as the brand representation of players who are working with Instant Book. And so we will be in dialogue with TripAdvisor when we can, although I wouldn't expect anything to happen soon. As far as the HomeAway new subscriptions and the change between PPB and subscription, I think it remains to be seen. I do think that one way or the other, more and more players are going to come online and make their listings online bookable. Whether they want to go through subscription or paper booking is we're fairly neutral to. And really, we just want to take it easy for our users to become online bookable. And the ones who become online bookable are obviously over at the long-term going to see the majority of demand in that marketplace because it's clearly what our consumers want. And ultimately, we think this is going to be a win-win in the marketplace when consumer expectations are met with homeowners and property managers. That's really what this model change is all about.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a little bit about hotel supply growth. I think you added 25,000 hotels in the quarter. It was a very big number. Can you talk about key drivers in there? Is there any seasonality? Just how we should be thinking about that?
componenttext: I wanted to ask a little bit about hotel supply growth. I think you added 25,000 hotels in the quarter. It was a very big number. Can you talk about key drivers in there? Is there any seasonality? Just how we should be thinking about that?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say on that one, it's business as usual as far as adding the 25,000 hotels. It's growth of about 20% on a year-on-year basis. And I think the team is just getting into a rhythm. As you know, we invested in our partner service team probably around
componenttext: Yes, I'd say on that one, it's business as usual as far as adding the 25,000 hotels. It's growth of about 20% on a year-on-year basis. And I think the team is just getting into a rhythm. As you know, we invested in our partner service team probably around 2 years ago. We really started investing in the sales team, and we continued to invest in that sales team, and they continued to deliver. If there's any seasonality, I'd say that we tried to bring on a bunch of hotels prior to the big summer season when travelers are traveling. So usually, the beginning of the year, Q1 and Q2, the team really tries to sign up as many hoteliers and partners as we can. And probably during the summer, we're a little more focused on managing rates and managing inventory and managing promotions, so that we can deliver as much volume to our partners as we can. But I think you should take the 25,000 as nothing unusual. It's going to be business as usual. And I think every quarter, we're going to add some amount close to that number. Whether it's a little bit lower or a little bit higher, really doesn't matter. I think from a long-term perspective, you should look at supply addition as being a growth factor for this business. And then when we had the HomeAway inventory, that will be a little bit of a boost.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from Brad Erickson with Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: And we have a question from Brad Erickson with Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up, I guess, from a previous question on some of the mix shifts you talked about independents from larger chains. Given the way you pursue those channels that targeted ROIs, to what degree might you pursue the independent segment more aggres
componenttext: Just a follow-up, I guess, from a previous question on some of the mix shifts you talked about independents from larger chains. Given the way you pursue those channels that targeted ROIs, to what degree might you pursue the independent segment more aggressively to capture sort of outsized growth at the expense of some profitability in the future? Or is it more of a case of growth expectations kind of status quo but with an improved margin profile going forward? How should we think about that?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen. If our business -- if the fundamentals of our business have changed as a result of what's going on with the chains, we might react. We just haven't seen any fundamentals change. So chain-heavy markets, chain-light markets are really acting the sam
componenttext: Listen. If our business -- if the fundamentals of our business have changed as a result of what's going on with the chains, we might react. We just haven't seen any fundamentals change. So chain-heavy markets, chain-light markets are really acting the same as they always have. So for us, it's about kind of rolling forward with the formula that we have in place, which is adding to supply, driving conversion improvements on the site, using those conversion improvements to fund additional marketing and then keeping those new users in the marketplace through loyalty programs both at Hotels.com and Expedia. So we'll watch it. The margin improvements are probably going to be a financial positive, but it's not really an agenda on the margin side. We're really trying to offer the best hotel at the best rate to our consumers, and that's what we're solving for. Everything else kind of flows from there. I would say that in every market, we are making sure that we have a wide selection of hotels that are providing us the best inventory at the best price. So we do look at the market-by-market basis. Sometimes, we even look at neighborhood by neighborhood to make sure that where there are neighborhoods that are specially popular, we have a wide selection of hotels. We work with those hotels on inventory and pricing and promotion and sort, et cetera. And so far, the results have been good, and it's something that we'll watch quite closely.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And that does conclude the question-and-answer session. I'll now turn the conference back over to you for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Thanks, everybody, for joining. We look forward to talking to you again next quarter. Dara, any closing remarks?
componenttext: Okay. Great. Thanks, everybody, for joining. We look forward to talking to you again next quarter. Dara, any closing remarks?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just that we're very, very pleased with activity that we see across the portfolio of brands that we have. The new additions have clearly been terrific, the HomeAways, trivagos of the world. There's a lot of really good work growing across the company
componenttext: Yes. Just that we're very, very pleased with activity that we see across the portfolio of brands that we have. The new additions have clearly been terrific, the HomeAways, trivagos of the world. There's a lot of really good work growing across the company. We see the competitive environment as tougher than it ever has been. The integration work that we're doing clearly has had some execution challenges, and the macro environment is a tough one. But this company has gained share year in, year out regardless of the environment. And I think with the strategic scope that we have now with the scope and metasearch, alternative lodging and the scale that we have, with the many brands that we have within our OTA business, we're a better positioned than we ever have been. So we expect excellent execution go-forward basis and nothing less than they wanted to thank our employees for the great work this year and the great work coming up. So thank you.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
